INTERJECT.PARA: Mr Klein said it may be that the Minister would have to sort the matter out with the Prime Minister.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable gentleman for his question and note that the Opposition is still seeking to insinuate some sinister cover-up by implying that in this case there are now some further suggestions of something improper in this matter. —You don't want him on his feet.

—The Leader of the Opposition had the opportunity to debate this last week but he chickened out because he is chicken. The Leader of the Opposition was too chicken last week to have a go. —I ask the Leader of the Opposition not to give me this business about not having a debate. We were waiting for it last week. We wanted it. But the Leader of the Opposition could not face up to it, in the same way as he cannot face up to the President of his Party and in the same way as he dodged the issue on the Sunday program yesterday. ANSWER.PARA: Let us get this matter quite clear. I will go through the sequence of events. On my return from leave on 31 December I issued a full Press release listing my role and my stance in the theatre contract issue. As the honourable gentleman who asked the question will recall, I issued a further Press release on 11 January when my Department responded to a freedom of information request by the Leader of the Opposition. There was nothing further I could have added to those statements in making any explanation to the House. As to the so-called latest revelations that may have incited the honourable gentleman to ask his question-revelations which caused the Leader of the Opposition to get a little bit excited on the Sunday program yesterday-I reiterate that I never expressed a view as to the voting numbers or right to vote of members of the panel. I remind the honourable gentleman and the House, as I said in my Press release on 31 December 1987:

. . . the numbers relating to a voting position in a tender assessment panel is a particular detail which by no stretch of anyone's imagination, however fevered, would on the face of it have entailed the Prime Minister's involvement.

The Minister informed me of the difficulties being encountered in obtaining the views of the panel as a whole and of his intention to ensure that all the artistic members of the panel contributed their advice on the intrinsic merits of the competing tenders. I concurred in that intention and agreed that their views were important and relevant-as they obviously were.

As I said then, and as I repeat: my involvement at all times was proper and appropriate. It was minimal. I do not spend my time second guessing my Ministers by watching their every move. I have had no reason to do that and I have no reason now. Indeed, the documents show that my attention was drawn to problems about the tender processes in mid-February last year. The honourable gentleman who asked the question would be aware of that fact. Within a matter of days of that being done I had taken steps to see that the Cabinet agreed on measures which would avoid potential problems. Mr Brown, in his then capacity as the Minister, carried out the direction of the Cabinet. The result of that adherence to proper procedures was announced in April when the contract was in fact given to AAV Australia Pty Ltd. As far as I was concerned, the matter was at an end. That is perfectly clear. In regard to these so-called latest revelations, I have answered quite clearly and unequivocally the questions put to me. Mr Brown has indicated that he accepts and agrees with what I have said.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL AUSTRALIAN NAVY: WESTERN AUSTRALIAN SHIP-LIFT FACILITY

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Defence. Has he seen comments from the shadow Minister concerning the new Western Australian ship-lift facility? I ask the Minister: Are there sufficient docking and maintenance facilities in Western Australia to support half the Navy fleet when it moves there?

—I thank the honourable member for her question and the diligent interest with which she pursues these matters that affect her electorate. It is planned, as the Government has announced previously, to move half the fleet to Western Australia, and that plan will take 10 years to implement. We are about a year or two into the implementation of it. The Royal Australian Navy (RAN) has no plans to base port the guided missile destroyers, the DDGs, in the west during the first five years of this process. The Navy is planning in the longer term to base port FFGs in the west. Timing is dependent on a number of factors, including the development of sufficient infrastructure in Western Australian industry, including depot level capability. The ship-lift, which was the subject of the honourable member's question, has been designed to be built in two phases. Phase one, which the Commonwealth is supporting, will be adequate to handle destroyer escorts and RAN submarines, both Oberons and the new ones. Phase 2, which will probably be undertaken in three to four years time, specifically aims to upgrade the ship-lift to handle vessels of up to 12,000 tonnes-sufficient to cope with the RAN FFGs. So the plans for upgrading our facilities in Western Australia to bring about the Government's policy of a two-ocean Navy are well in hand and proceeding satisfactorily.

QUESTION.PARA: The Prime Minister is aware that I have requested a meeting of the full committee.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, you will recall what I have said in my Press releases and what I have repeated here. It was brought to my attention in February that there was some suggestion of a problem with the processes that had been followed. As I have said in my Press releases, and I have said again here, within a matter of days I ensured that this matter would come before the Cabinet. It did come before the Cabinet. As a result of the Cabinet decision, the Minister proceeded with the further meeting of the panel. That was the sequence of events. I had it brought to my attention in February that there were some problems, the circumstances of which are known. When I was not satisfied that it could be left in that circumstance, I took it to the--
—Sloppy.
—If the honourable member wants to say `sloppy'--
—You said that.
—Okay, I used that word. But if the honourable member is saying that the Minister was sloppy, I will repeat--
—You said that.

—Of course I did; I said it in this House. It appears that members of the Opposition get some satisfaction from getting back at the ex-Minister by saying that the Prime Minister referred to him as sloppy. But, to be fair to the ex-Minister, if the Opposition wants to quote me saying that, let it quote the rest of what I said. The rest of what I said was that he had done an outstanding job. Opposition members should be fair to the man. Yes, I said that the honourable member for Parramatta had been sloppy in some aspects of this matter, but I said that he did an absolutely outstanding job, not just for this Government but for this country, in the areas of tourism and sport. A comparison of the efforts of the honourable member for Parramatta with the pygmy efforts put in over a period of some 23 years by those opposite when they had responsibility ought to make them ashamed. The honourable member for Parramatta stands out like a mountain against the molehill of their achievements. If members of the Opposition think that it does them any credit, when talking about this man, to refer to one thing and say, `On that aspect the Prime Minister said that he was sloppy,' and think that they have exhausted an assessment in any sort of fairness of the man's achievements, that is consistent with the mean-minded way in which they approach politics. ANSWER.PARA: When it was brought to my attention in February that there were some problems in regard to aspects of the handling of this matter I immediately took steps to bring the matter before Cabinet. The Minister, in carrying out the decision of Cabinet, called a further meeting. In fairness to the Minister, I want to repeat the point I have made. Let us just look at the arithmetic of the matter. If the question of the artistic membership had not been predominant in his mind, what was the point of his having another meeting at any rate? He could not possibly win. If the question of the public servants was absolutely predominant in his mind, on that basis he was down 4 : 2 in the voting. If he called Mr Faiman in, there was no way in which he could win; the vote would still be 4 : 3 against him. As to what was in the former Minister's mind, it is quite clear, as is stated in paragraph 9 of the document he read the other day, that, as far as the Minister was concerned, the overwhelmingly important issue was the split of the vote between the artistic members. So the procedures followed by the former Minister were in pursuit of the Cabinet decision, the Cabinet consideration of this matter, which followed my bringing of the matter before the Cabinet.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs inform the House of his response to media criticism that the time taken to issue visitor visas in Tokyo has been increasing?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —At present the office in Tokyo is receiving about 850 visa applications a day. That is almost 60 per cent higher than the figure a year ago. Arrangements have been made to employ extra locally-engaged staff and to extend employment to two others whose work contracts were about to expire. Procedures have been re-examined and further refined and streamlined. The immediate aim is one of issuing all visas within 48 hours, and we believe that can be achieved in the immediate future. This will eventually be reduced to 24 hours, with visas issued on the spot when requested. That will depend upon the installation of new and updated technology which is designed to improve service standards. The Department is in the process of putting that in place.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Prime Minister seen the memorandum prepared in his Department on 22 December 1987 on the resignation of the former Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories? I ask in particular whether the Prime Minister has seen that part of that memorandum which says:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . Mr Glenn of DOLGAS cleared with his Minister and with the Prime Minister's office that Mr Hillier and Mr Rubie (the two public servants on the Assessment Panel) would be on the panel to assess submissions for the theatre. We were unaware of this.

Did the Prime Minister's office clear the appointments of the two public servants to the panel? If so, can the Prime Minister tell us why his former Minister continues to say that the two public servants were not members of the panel with full voting entitlements?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have made it clear, and I repeat it to the honourable gentleman, that, obviously, as this matter has arisen, I have gone back over all the documents, including the one that has been referred to, although just quickly looking at my notes, I think it was dated 21 December. I think the honourable gentleman said it was the 22nd.
—He is right, too. There are two of them.

—Fair enough. I just looked quickly at the notes and saw one dated 21 December. Not only have I looked at the documents in this matter but also, clearly, I have discussed it with my Department and my officials. There is nothing in any document, and nothing has emerged from the discussions that I have had, which gives any reason at all to change the statements that I have made by way of public release, media release, or in this place.

ANSWER.PARA: As to that part of the question from the honourable gentleman which goes to what was in the mind of the ex-Minister, the honourable member for Parramatta, that is clearly a question for him, although in the forms of this House it cannot be directed to him. Let me say on that point that the honourable member for Parramatta has made it quite clear that he accepts and agrees with what I have said on this issue as to the membership and voting rights or otherwise of the members of that panel. I repeat: it must be said in fairness to the honourable member that on the record it has been established quite clearly what was in his mind as to where the matter lay.

One can take it to the next step. Let us assume, just for the sake of discussion, that in regard to Mr Faiman, who was the fifth of the five artistic members to come in, as it turned out in the event when the meeting was reconvened his vote, if we can put it in shorthand terms, went against Rogers and in favour of AAV Australia Pty Ltd. In the mind of the Minister that was absolutely decisive. For the sake of speculation, let us say that the vote had gone the other way, that Mr Faiman's vote had gone in favour of Rogers and against AAV. In the circumstances, I imagine what the Minister would have done would have been to report to Cabinet as to the outcome-that three of the artistic members were in favour of Rogers and two in favour of AAV. It would have been known what the position of the others was and the Cabinet would have been confronted with a decision as to what it should do in those circumstances. It would have had the report.

I repeat that as far as what was in the mind of the Minister is concerned, clearly the arithmetic of it shows that there would not have been any point in his calling or going ahead with a meeting to that effect unless he thought in terms of its being decisive for him as to the view of the artistic members. The arithmetic shows that, if it was not the case, he was outvoted anyway.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for the Arts and Territories. In asking the Minister his maiden question, I want to congratulate him on his elevation to the Ministry. He will be one of the great Ministers of this Government.
—Is this a dorothy dixer?
—No, this is without notice. Is the Australian film industry facing financial difficulties? What is the Government's response?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Punch The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question and his congratulations. There is no doubt that the Australian film industry has some fairly serious problems. The latest report I have is that the level of fund raising for film and television drama is expected to drop from about $140m last year to between $30m and $40m for 1987-88. Undoubtedly, I say to the House, the overwhelming reason for that reduction is the reduction in income tax rates that has been brought about by this Government, which has made tax concessions available for investment in film far less attractive to investors than they have ever been.

ANSWER.PARA: Given that, I should inform the House that last week I met with representatives of the Australian Film Commission and the Australian film industry and, on behalf of the Government, I gave them an undertaking that we will be aiming to have a new film assistance scheme in place by 1 July this year and a decision is to be made next month on exactly which type of scheme. We on this side of the House-I hope honourable members on the other side will listen-believe in the Australian film industry. We think it is culturally very important to the people of this country and we intend to make sure that film production in this country continues at a high level.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Prime Minister and refer him to the comments made by the honourable member for Parramatta that the Prime Minister shared his own view that the two public servant members on the second tendering committee for the Expo theatre pavilion did not have a vote in awarding the contract. In view of the fact that the honourable member for Parramatta subsequently requested that his comments on this matter not be published because it was not in the Prime Minister's-to use the honourable member's words-`best interests', will the Prime Minister inform the House of any circumstances which would not make the publication of this view by the honourable member for Parramatta be in his best interests? In other words, as the honourable member for Parramatta appeared to suggest, does the Prime Minister have a problem if the truth is told about him in this matter?

—I feel quite devastated by this question. The fact is that I tell the truth. As can be expected from the fact that I always tell the truth, I have told the truth on this issue. It is the case that the honourable member for Parramatta seemed to have a misunderstanding and he has accepted without qualification the statements that I have made. He has made that clear today, as I understand it. He has made it quite clear that he accepts that. I repeat: it is a measure of the pathetic quality of the people opposite and their leader that in a situation where there is so much discussion about the economy, here in this country and in the international context, we went for the whole of last week without a question on the Australian economy from the opposite side to the Treasurer or me. This is now the fourth question on this matter to be asked today. There was some hope when the Deputy Leader of the Opposition stood up that he might at last have summoned up courage to direct a question to his opposite number, the Treasurer, on the economy. But Opposition members go on in this way because all they have is their squalid, misplaced hope that we on this side of the House have the same standards of integrity that they have. Unfortunately for them, our standards are infinitely superior. They can go on for as long as they like. They can ask as many questions as they like. They can do this week what they did not have the courage to do last week and move a censure motion if they like. We do not mind how long they take on this by way of question to me or by way of censure motion. We would welcome it. They can go on as long as they like because the further they go on this issue the further they will sink in the estimation of the people of this country.

—Is the Minister for Social Security aware of action taken by some States to include the family allowance supplement (FAS) in the calculation of Housing Commission rentals? If he is aware, as I would expect to be the case, can he inform the House what action has been taken by the Commonwealth to protect the integrity of the family package payments?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for her question. I know that she and a number of members of the Parliament are concerned that the treatment of the family allowance supplement by the State housing departments is extremely important, particularly given the Commonwealth's commitment to the elimination of child poverty. I inform the House that Senator Ryan, when she was the responsible Minister, wrote to the State Ministers asking them to give consideration to concessional treatment of the family allowance supplement on the basis that if the full amount of the supplement were taken into account it would contradict the Government's emphasis and initiative with respect to the elimination of child poverty.

ANSWER.PARA: The current Minister with responsibility for that portfolio has further pursued the matter. He informs me that State officials met last week and gave consideration to the matter. There was a recognition of the Commonwealth's objective with respect to child poverty and a recognition that it may well be appropriate to review procedures for assessing income and rent for low income parents in the light of the additional payments they are receiving from the family package. The Government is certainly very anxious to see consistent treatment across all the States. To that end, my colleague the Minister for Housing and Aged Care shortly will write to State housing Ministers seeking an approach in line with that discussed by officials.

We welcome very much the positive steps being taken by State officials and governments to reconsider this extremely important matter. I might say, incidentally, that the only Commonwealth area in which it seems there is very strong resistance to reconsideration of the issue is on the part of the Queensland Government which has said on a number of occasions that it will not undertake a review of the income rebate policy. Of course, that Government has been taking account of the earlier family income supplement payment. I very much regret the Queensland Government's position. We have had very fruitful discussions with that Government on the child support scheme and I think there was some willingness to co-operate in that area.

It is extremely important that the child poverty issue be addressed nationally, by not only the Commonwealth but also all the States. There are perhaps stronger reasons that Queensland, more than any other State, should address this issue. As honourable members will know, Queensland has had extraordinarily high levels of unemployment. December 1987 was the twenty-second month in a row that Queensland had more people on the unemployment benefit than Victoria-98,817 compared with 83,577-whereas Victoria's work force is 65 per cent higher than Queensland's. Queensland has the highest unemployment of any State-a figure of 9.6 per cent compared with 7.8 per cent nationally. Given the unemployment that exists in Queensland and the reality of poverty that goes with those levels of unemployment, it would seem to me responsible for the Queensland Government to reconsider its position and, at the appropriate time, together with other Ministers, help us to achieve a genuinely national approach in terms of the treatment of FAS and the elimination of child poverty.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Prime Minister whether he or anyone on his behalf had any discussion with the honourable member for Parramatta regarding the substance of the article on the front page of the Weekend Australian containing the allegation by the honourable member for Parramatta and former Minister that the Prime Minister shared his view about voting rights on the Expo panel and also containing the entreaty of the honourable member for Parramatta that that comment not be published.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I answer this question, which I will of course, I ask the House to note that it seems to be a new facet of the Leader of the Opposition's approach that it is appropriate to disclose in this place discussions that take place between leading members of it and other people. He went on with it last week. He wanted to suggest to this House that it was proper, for instance, that I should disclose to this House discussions that I had had with the President of my Party. I remind the House that the President of my Party is Mr M. J. Young. If the Leader of the Opposition thinks it is appropriate to disclose to this House discussions that I have had with the President of my Party, it would be interesting to see whether he would play the same game and disclose to this House why the President of his Party, on 5 February in Adelaide, told him that last year he was not fit to be the Prime Minister of a Liberal government in this country. ANSWER.PARA: In answer to the question asked by the Leader of the Opposition, I had discussions with the honourable member for Parramatta because it was appropriate to do that, as clearly he had misunderstood this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —You misunderstood it. You got it together at last?

—No, there was no misunderstanding. I shall indicate to the Leader of the Opposition precisely the events of last Thursday when this matter arose. On Thursday afternoon I was leaving Parliament House to go to Melbourne. Some 10 minutes before I left the matter was brought to the attention of my Press officer that the honourable member for Parramatta had made certain observations. The factual position of the Prime Minister was conveyed to the honourable member for Parramatta. Then we left. Naturally, I do not think that the Leader of the Opposition would be surprised to learn that I did discuss this matter with the honourable member for Parramatta. I make no attempt to disguise the fact that I did discuss the matter with the honourable member. There should be no smirk of satisfaction on the face of the Leader of the Opposition. That was a perfectly natural thing to do-perfectly natural. The honourable member for Parramatta accepts the position I put to him. It is not surprising that he should, because that position is factually correct.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Has the Minister any response from the State governments on the Government's Green Paper on Higher Education? Do the States support the thrust of the Green Paper's proposals?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to be able to report to the honourable member and to the House that on Friday of last week there was a special meeting of the Australian Education Council to consider the Government's proposals in relation to higher education. The importance of that is that whatever we do in the area of higher education has great implications for the States, in terms of the numbers of young people who are likely to enrol in higher secondary schools, the curriculum they might undertake, and most particularly, improved links between the technical and further education system and the higher education system as we now know it.

ANSWER.PARA: After a long discussion during the meeting on Friday, the members of the Council agreed in principle to the three basic thrusts of the Green Paper: they supported the need for a strongly growing higher education system; they supported one that would run as efficiently as possible; and they supported one where quality of teaching and research would be safeguarded and enriched during the process.

As a consequence of that agreement in principle, it was decided to establish in each State a joint planning committee in order to progress matters of detail as they will affect each State. Many issues will touch on State responsibilities in relation to the possible amalgamation of institutions. They include improved credit transfers between institutions, and an array of other matters. We are keen as quickly as possible to examine in some detail the States' views, and what they would like to see done in their States. We are keen because we want to use that input as an important contribution to the development of our White Paper later this year.

With regard to other contributions to this debate, I might add that on 16 February the Australian Committee of Directors and Principals in Advanced Education issued a statement in which it strongly supported the clear vision underlying the initiatives proposed in the Government's Green Paper. We are still awaiting the vice-chancellors' response. However, I have had a meeting with the executive of the Vice-Chancellors Committee, and I expect, again, a very positive response from the vice-chancellors.

I do not want to indicate here that there will be unqualified, 100 per cent, support for all of the proposals. After all, this is a Green Paper intended to stimulate debate, a debate in which the Government is keen to participate. As a result of broad discussion during the next couple of months I am sure that we will be able to secure a strong foundation for the growth of higher education towards the turn of the century.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the Prime Minister that we have now reached the situation in which the honourable member for Parramatta resigned because he misled the Parliament but refused to tell the Parliament how this occurred. He then asserted that the Prime Minister held the view which caused him to mislead Parliament. He then claimed that by telling the truth he had been misleading about the Prime Minister's knowledge of the matter, and he now maintains that the Press is being misleading by telling the truth. Does the Prime Minister still believe that the honourable member for Parramatta is a fit and proper person to return to his Ministry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I made it quite clear before that I believe that in certain respects the former Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories had been sloppy in his handling of this matter. I have said that in the House and I have said it to him. I have also said to him, as I have to this House, that I believe that he did a simply outstanding job as the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, as it was originally, and then in his enlarged capacity after the rearrangements of last year. I have no reason to change that assessment, that judgment, which I have conveyed to the honourable member for Parramatta personally and have also made public.

ANSWER.PARA: In the balance of considerations, testing the sloppiness of this issue on the one hand and looking at the enormous achievements of John Brown as a Minister on the other, I have no reason to change my assessment that at some time in the future it would not be inappropriate that the great talents of the honourable member for Parramatta should be made available again to the government and people of this country. In saying that, I did not convey, nor did I intend to convey, that that was something for the immediate future; nor have I conveyed that to the honourable member. In this regard I give some gratuitous advice to the Leader of the Opposition. —Can the Treasurer indicate to the House the condition of State financial outlays and borrowings?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the last week or two there has been a debate in the Press about the condition of various State finances and some reference to those in New South Wales, particularly in light of statements by the Leader of the Opposition in New South Wales in the last few days that were he to have his way, a government led by him would freeze public outlays in New South Wales. The point of this utterance on the part of the New South Wales Leader of the Opposition, no doubt, is that he feels that it will endow him with some particular virtue. However, the fact of the matter is that the New South Wales Government not only does not have outlays frozen but also it is actually reducing the size of outlays. This year public outlays in New South Wales are set to decline by minus one per cent in real terms.

ANSWER.PARA: It is interesting that the New South Wales Leader of the Opposition is talking about some rigour, albeit of a subordinate variety, in the New South Wales Government in public administration when his Federal counterpart ran around in an election campaign with $8 billion in unfunded tax cuts and who, in the interregnum, has decided that he will take Commonwealth outlays back to some average that applied between the late 1960s and early 1970s which would cut about $11 billion from public outlays. Of course, he has not specified where those cuts would be made.

The fact of the matter is that the Liberal Party of Australia has had its chance to do something to the national economy. It has failed as, in particular, the Leader of the Opposition has failed. I think it is worth placing on the record that New South Wales Government outlays to State gross product were the lowest of all the States through the 1980s. Not only are outlays growing negatively this year by one per cent in real terms, but also the net borrowing requirement for New South Wales is estimated to fall by 9.2 per cent in real terms in 1987-88 against minus 2.8 per cent for all other States, including the Northern Territory. Therefore, both on outlays and borrowings the New South Wales position is tighter than that of any of the other States. Its net borrowings are estimated at 1.6 per cent of State gross product-less than the all-State average and the second lowest of all the States.

We can see that when the New South Wales Premier wishes to say that he would allocate spending to priorities set by him and his Government, he can do that as, indeed, the Commonwealth Government this year has set its priorities within an outlays growth figure of minus 2.4 per cent in real terms. It has been able to introduce the family allowance supplement as part of the family package, increase pensions to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings and make various other expenditure commitments and set priorities for the Federal Government within the rigour of a minus 2.4 per cent growth in real terms. In other words, it is the right of any government to change the spending priorities of its predecessors, which we have done by a rigorous evaluation of priorities from 1983 onwards and which New South Wales has been doing in the last 12 years, and continues to do. It is an entirely reasonable proposition for a Premier of any State to order priorities as he or she, as the case may be, sees fit in relation to the spending of that State. At the moment we have the debate about how the New South Wales Liberal Party, chastened by the defeat of the Federal Liberal Party with its grab bag of unfunded promises, has decided that it will freeze spending when its counterpart party, the Government of New South Wales, has spending decreasing-not just frozen, but declining.

In mentioning the change in the priorities of the New South Wales Government, it is also worth recalling that over the past 12 years there has been a dramatic change in priorities in New South Wales. They have been Labor priorities set by a Labor government-by the Wran Government and the Unsworth Government. If people cast their minds back, the fact is that 12 years ago New South Wales was in industrial ruin. Under Federal and State Liberal policies we had the decimation of the great industrial heartland of Sydney. We saw the decimation of the satellite cities of Wollongong and Newcastle. We saw the priorities of spending cast away from the centres of population in the western suburbs where there were unsewered areas of unguttered streets.

Since Labor has been in government in New South Wales we have seen the return of decent services with an extension of rail and transport services throughout the western region of New South Wales. On top of that, we have seen the revitalisation of the whole industrial base in New South Wales in the hands of both Premier Wran and Premier Unsworth. There has been very definitely a change and a resetting of priorities for public outlays within the State of New South Wales, particularly through the 1980s, so that today New South Wales is the leading industrial State, where the job growth rate in 1987 was double that of the rest of Australia, where half of all new Australian jobs were created in 1987 and where half of all private sector job vacancies occurred. That shows the progress of the State of New South Wales from the industrial shambles that the Liberal Party had left it in when Premier Wran picked it up in 1976. It shows the way in which Labor set its priorities and reinvigorated the place. We have seen great cosmopolitan changes in Sydney not only to the industrial base but also to the fact that, on weekends particularly, it had been a place nobody could visit because it was shut down. Things have changed dramatically for people who do not have the privilege of a harbourside home. They can now go to Darling Harbour, which the Liberal Party was happy to leave as a railway goods yard, or to Pier One, Walsh Bay, Macquarie Street, the gardens or the Art Gallery. The fact is that Sydney has come to life as the throbbing, beating centre of the Federation in terms of its industrial activity. It is the most cosmopolitan of the capital cities. This has all been done by Labor governments. All of the great changes in the city of Sydney, such as the electrification of the rail lines to the west and the Opera House, have been brought about by Labor governments. Labor governments will continue to set the priorities in New South Wales. We will not need to be told by any hand-me-down Liberal leader about freezing outlays when we can change priorities the Labor way, but change them with outlays to the State gross product in a way which is far tighter and more rigorous than is the case in any coalition-run State in the Commonwealth.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended that would prevent the Prime Minister and the Member for Parramatta providing the House forthwith a full explanation of the facts surrounding the resignation of the Member for Parramatta from the Ministry with particular reference to the Prime Minister's knowledge of the voting procedures for the theatre contract at Expo 88.

All of the bluster and the irrelevance of the answers given by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) at Question Time cannot disguise one simple and fundamental fact-that the affair involving the resignation from the Ministry of the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr John Brown), but, more importantly, involving the standards of propriety of the Hawke Ministry, has assumed absolute Fawlty Towers proportions. The one and only way in which this issue can be resolved is for the honourable member for Parramatta to get up on his hind legs and to give, not to a journalist, not to the Prime Minister, not to his mates in the Ministry and not to his mates in the Australian Labor Party, but to the Parliament of Australia, some explanation in detail of why he misled this Parliament and why he resigned. That is the only way to resolve this matter, and I have moved a motion to suspend Standing Orders to allow the honourable member for Parramatta to do that.

I ask the question: Why will the Prime Minister not allow the honourable member for Parramatta to get on his feet? Why does the Prime Minister want to prevent the honourable member for Parramatta from being as candid to this Parliament as he was to the journalist who reported him verbatim on Saturday morning? I wonder whether the Prime Minister has listened to the tape recording of the interview between the journalist and the former Minister. It is available in the office of News Ltd for anybody who wants to hear it. One can then make a judgment for oneself as to the nature of the conversation which the Prime Minister admitted took place between him and his former Minister after that article appeared on Saturday morning.

It is all very well for the Prime Minister to bluster; it is all very well for us to have a sentimental defence of the honourable member for Parramatta by the Prime Minister, but this Parliament is the body to which Ministers, Prime Ministers and backbenchers who have been Ministers, are ultimately accountable. On this occasion we have been treated with utter contempt. The Prime Minister can use the brute force of his parliamentary numbers, he can give his smart alec answers and he can turn around to those who sit beside him and behind him to draw some comfort from their orchestrated cheers and their orchestrated encouragement, but nothing alters the fact that the honourable member for Parramatta resigned on 17 December and at no stage has this Parliament been treated to so much as the courtesy of a full and proper explanation. Even while this motion is being debated, the honourable member for Parramatta walks out of the chamber, joining the Prime Minister in the utter contempt in which he holds this Parliament and this chamber in particular.

How extraordinary it is that a Minister resigns because he misled Parliament but offers no explanation. He then, in the course of a long rambling interview, said that the matter over which he resigned was common ground between himself and the Prime Minister. Common ground! There is no suggestion that the verbatim report in the Weekend Australian is wrong. I challenge the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley), who is at the table, I challenge the Prime Minister, and I challenge the former Minister to verify any assertion on their part that this article is wrong.

This article is very illuminating because not only does it say that the former Minister believed that the Prime Minister had the same view as he did about the voting procedures, but also, on top of that, after realising the import of what he had said, he then pleaded with the journalist not to publish what he had said. What was the reason he gave? The reason he gave was that it would not advance the interests of the Prime Minister if he were to have published what he had said. In other words, we have reached a situation in this country where it is legitimate to suppress the truth because the publication of the truth would be embarrassing to the Prime Minister.

The Prime Minister and his colleagues may trivialise this matter. They may say that it is irrelevant. The Prime Minister may beg us to ask questions of the Treasurer (Mr Keating); he will keep. We are interested today in what the Prime Minister has got to say about the standards of his Government. He was great when he was in Opposition in talking about standards. When Phillip Lynch was under fire over a matter of which he was totally exonerated, nobody shouted louder from the roof tops than did the present Prime Minister. When the former Attorney-General in the Fraser Government was under fire, nobody shouted louder from the roof tops that did the present Prime Minister. When some of my other colleagues were under fire there was nobody louder in his criticism than the present Prime Minister. Nobody paraded his outraged sense of propriety with greater venom and transparency than did the present Prime Minister.

In an interview on 16 November 1977, the Prime Minister summed it all up when he said, `If a man shouts from the roof tops that those in high office should be subject to scrutiny he should have exactly those standards applied to himself'. That is exactly what we are doing. Nobody shouts louder from the roof tops, nobody parades his integrity more with such pathetic sensitivity, than does the present Prime Minister. He cannot let a statement pass his lips without saying how honest he is and how he always tells the truth. If he always tells the truth and he is so honest, why is he so frightened of this Parliament hearing from John Brown? Why is he so craven in his desire to prevent John Brown coming into this Parliament, getting up on his hind legs and saying, `This is how it happened'? Why? Until John Brown does that, until this craven Prime Minister, whose precious concern for his integrity blinds his judgment, allows Brown to come into this Parliament, his responses--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Leader of the Opposition might refer to the honourable member for Parramatta by his electorate.

—Until the Prime Minister allows the honourable member for Parramatta to come into this Parliament and explain to this chamber, to which he is accountable, why it is that the events that have transpired occurred in the manner that they did, we can draw only one conclusion. However trivial the Prime Minister may want the public and the Press to think this matter is, we can draw only one conclusion, and that is that the Prime Minister is frightened of the truth, that he is frightened of what would happen if the honourable member for Parramatta got on his hind legs and actually explained. Who believes what the honourable member for Parramatta and the Prime Minister now say in the face of the most explicit language used by the honourable member for Parramatta, as reported in this newspaper interview? This is what the honourable member for Parramatta said:

SPEECH.PARA: I'm withdrawing that information. It was a mistake. I'm withdrawing it, right? And I don't want you to print it.

In other words, he was down on his bended knees pleading with the journalist not to publish it because it might dob in his mate the Prime Minister. I do not believe the honourable member for Parramatta when he said on the steps of Parliament House this morning that the newspaper report was wrong. I do not believe the Prime Minister's account in the Parliament today. Of course, he had a word with the honourable member for Parramatta. Undoubtedly, he said to the honourable member for Parramatta, `You have got it wrong again, John. This is too embarrassing for me. How are we going to handle this matter?'. That is how they got together. Of course they had a conversation. I say again that this matter will remain a cloud over the Hawke Ministry until the honourable member for Parramatta, as is his bounden duty, gives this Parliament, in accordance with its right, a full account, a proper explanation and a truthful story regarding all of the circumstances that surround this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Is the motion seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion. There are three reasons why this motion should be seconded and why the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr John Brown) should make a full statement to the House about the whole matter concerning a World Expo 88 contract for $5m. The first reason is that it is fundamental to our system of parliamentary democracy that Ministers are answerable to the people through the Parliament of this country. They are members of Parliament. When they resign they have an obligation to this House to make a statement as to why they resign. Since this Parliament has reassembled, neither we nor the Australian people have been given the courtesy or the decency of an explanation as to why this Minister resigned and what the Prime Minister knows about it. If the Prime Minister, the honourable member for Parramatta and the Government as a whole had an ounce of respect for this principle of parliamentary democracy-the principle that Ministers are answerable to the Parliament-they would agree to this motion to set aside standing orders and the Prime Minister and the honourable member would make their statements to this House. They would not run off and make statements to the Press, deny them later on and then add insult to injury by abusing the Press; they would come into this House and make statements. If that principle has been abused, as it clearly has, it has been doubly abused by the Prime Minister and the honourable member for Parramatta walking out of this House while this debate is in progress. They have shown absolute and complete contempt for this Parliament and for the principle of ministerial responsibility.

SPEECH.PARA: The second reason this motion should be supported is that there is now a whole series of documents which show in fact that the Prime Minister was involved. He put out his stupid Press release on 31 December, in between golf matches, saying that this matter was too trivial for him to be concerned with. But what do we see when we look at the documents that are available under the Freedom of Information Act? We find that the public servants, who are presumably telling the truth-and there are several of them and they have produced a whole series of documents-are saying that the Prime Minister was involved. They say his office was involved. They say he was intimately concerned, not just with the issue as a whole but with the very issue which led to the Minister's resignation. So the Prime Minister is involved. The House is entitled to an explanation from him by way of statement as to the extent of his involvement, when he became involved and what his dealings were with the honourable member for Parramatta when he was a Minister. The House is entitled to an explanation of all of the circumstances. It will simply compound the offence that they have committed if the Prime Minister does not make that statement.

I think the third matter is somewhat new. The honourable member for Parramatta was sprung when the Sydney Morning Herald printed a document which showed that the former Minister had misled this House. That document, according to the honourable member for Parramatta, was leaked by a public servant-another smear, another piece of abuse thrown at the Public Service. I can tell you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that I believe-and I believe it on substantial grounds-that that document was not leaked by a public servant but by a Minister in the Hawke Government. Ministers were the ones who benefited most from getting rid of Brown. They were the ones who were responsible for those circumstances. They were the ones who, on my understanding, had the documents. It was only when the Ministers of this Government had the documents that one of them was leaked.

For 20 months 20 or so senior public servants handled hundreds and hundreds of pages of documents about this matter and not one of them leaked; all the documents remained in the departments. When I put in my freedom of information request I was told by the Department that documents had been recalled from many places. For the first time they were together in one place. I was told by the Department that it was then that they came into the hands of Ministers and not before. The documents were in the hands of Ministers. The senior public servant in the former Minister's Department said to me that the Department was not responsible for what Ministers did with the Government's property. For that reason, among others, I believe that that document was leaked by a Minister in the Hawke Government. It was that which sprang him. It was that which proved that he had misled the Parliament. It is no wonder the Government wants to continue this deception. When the honourable member for Parramatta was involved in the so-called colour television issue in 1982, he said on opening his speech in this place:
O what a tangled web we weave, when first we practise to deceive.
I can still hear him saying it in that debate. How true it is of this case. If the Government does not come clean, eventually it will get even more ensnared in this web.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a damp squib the Opposition has made of this issue. This is the second time it has put forward this proposition. As on the first occasion, no additional arguments have been presented as to why a statement should be made. The Opposition has come in here with perhaps the weakest preliminary to censure discussions that I have yet heard a Leader of the Opposition-admittedly I have only eight years experience-make in this place. First of all, the Opposition invited us to consider the point that, when somebody resigns, invariably a statement must be made to the Parliament. It happens to be the case that the Opposition's period of administration provided ample examples of resignation on grounds of propriety. There were something like 22 resignations, eight of which were on grounds of propriety. What was the result? We might say that it was mixed. On four occasions statements were indeed made to the Parliament. One honourable member opposite, who is leaning forward and listening to this very intently, was one of those who made a statement to the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: Apropos criticisms of the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr John Brown) returning to the Ministry, I notice that there is no difficulty at all-and I would say rightly so-on the part of the Opposition deciding that the concerns of the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) were of sufficient proportion to enable him to return to the front bench at some subsequent stage. Persiflage is being thrown around this place about that being an inadequate precedent or that the man must be driven from public office forever, which is not, of course, a policy practised by the Opposition.

From the researches that I have managed to undertake so far there were four cases in which statements were not made to Parliament. Vic Garland resigned as Minister for Post and Telecommunications because of allegations of electoral bribery leading to legal action. No statement was made in the Parliament. Phil Lynch resigned as Treasurer on 19 November 1977 over allegations that he had received special consideration from profitable land deals in 1976. No explanation was given to the Parliament. Glen Sheil resigned on 21 December 1977 after being named as a Minister on 20 December 1977. He was dismissed before being sworn in as Minister for Veterans' Affairs after making pro-apartheid statements contrary to Government policy. No explanation was given to the Parliament. Senator Withers resigned as Minister for Administrative Services after allegations of impropriety in the 1977 redistribution of Federal electoral boundaries in Queensland. In that instance there was a statement to the Parliament-a short one by the then Senator Carrick. Of course, we know that Mr Robinson resigned in here and then resubmitted himself as a member of the Government. He publicly resigned and retracted his resignation. In that instance Parliament was unable to discover what were the essential causes of his points of disagreement with the then Prime Minister and what brought him back.

So we have these great attempts by Opposition members to portray themselves as the defenders of parliamentary proprietry in this place-that every time somebody resigns there must be a statement to Parliament. They managed to practise that not one whit while they were in government. The House can judge their seriousness in this case by their performance and practices when they happened to be in government. So, we do not take any lectures from the Opposition on the subject of whether we appropriately manage our affairs in this House by the explanations that we give. That is the first point. The Opposition arrives here without any great robes of propriety, honesty, honourableness, or whatever they attempt to clothe themselves in.

The substance of the motion asks the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to explain in the House what he knew about the understanding of the honourable member for Parramatta as to who was entitled to vote or otherwise in the tender selection process. The Opposition's argument is that that has not been explained. I have been present during Question Times for the last week and a bit. To my memory there have been at least half a dozen questions going precisely to that point, to which the Prime Minister offered lengthy answers. The Prime Minister did not seek to duck or weave the issue. He said quite clearly that there were different understandings of the situation in the mind of the Minister and in the minds of the other people, including the Prime Minister, who were handling the matter. The Minister was quite clear in his mind as to what the voting procedures were. His understandings subsequently proved to be erroneous. The Minister had a defence on the question of whether he deliberately arrived at that erroneous conclusion. That is clear from memos that subsequently have been made the subject of freedom of information discussion. Obviously it was an honest mistake on his part. I shall speak more on that point when I speak on the question of ministerial propriety.

As far as the Prime Minister was concerned, the question was whether a full range of artistic advice had been given with regard to the tender being considered by the Government for the Australian Pavilion at Expo. The Prime Minister has made his position quite clear. He has done so publicly and in this House in answers to questions asked. Therefore no further explanation is needed. However, of further interest is the motives of the people involved in this unfortunate affair. One thing that emerges clearly from all of this is that, whatever mistakes were made by the honourable member for Parramatta in the administration of his portfolio, his motives were of the highest. His concern was to provide for this country the best possible display at a very important event in our bicentennial year. There is no question of that in any of his activities. His motive is supported by the fact that no personal gain was involved. Clearly all that was involved was a mistake in administration. That demonstrates how fundamentally and totally trivial the Opposition is in persistently raising this question. There was no attempt on the part of the Minister to take from the public purse. There was no attempt by him to do other than effectively administer his portfolio. Honourable members will recall what happened last year with regard to the question of tenders. The Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support was regularly excoriated by the Opposition on whether he would interfere in a tender process. Oh no, said the Opposition, the precious tender process must never be looked at by Government Ministers; interference must not take place. That is what the Opposition now says on this issue. But what did it say when that issue was before the House? It said that governments must interfere regularly in the tender process to take a serious interest in what is happening. I tend to agree with that process. All Ministers must carefully view the tender process in any matter dealing with their public administration. The Government would not disagree with that. Of course, that is exactly what the honourable member for Parramatta did.

Unfortunately the nature of affairs in this place is that a person can, by the way in which he conducts his portfolio, make a considerable effort in the public administration of this country in order to secure a great deal of public benefit-but be forced out on what is essentially a trivial matter. There is a considerable difference-I shall go straight to this matter-between misleading the Parliament and deliberately misleading the Parliament. The point has been clearly made by the Prime Minister and others that the honourable member for Parramatta adopted a stance on propriety with regard to his relationship to this Parliament that few other Ministers ever have. To this point there has been no requirement of any resignation that I have seen that says that a Minister who inadvertently misleads the House should resign.

TALK.START.PARA: —We don't accept that.

—The Leader of the Opposition may not accept that now but he did when his Party was in government. His Party regularly accepted it and he regularly corrected Minister's answers in this place. Opposition members regularly presented themselves here and answered positions given in Question Time that were ultimately misleading. So let us dismiss that nonsense for starters. The honourable member for Parramatta made a statement pointing out that he felt that his administration had been so totally inadequate that, while the resignation was not required of him by the Prime Minister and while there was no demand that that should proceed, he did not believe that he should any longer hold that position. He believed that his administration was inadvertently suspect. For that reason he decided to leave office.

SPEECH.PARA: As far as this matter is concerned, all the facts are on public record. They are on public record because of the Freedom of Information Act, Press releases and regular answers to questions in this Parliament. There is no further material to be placed on the public record. Therefore, the demand by the Opposition that we make further parliamentary statements on this is ridiculous. The Opposition has managed over the last week or so to blow its chances.

That the introduction of time-charging for local telephone calls by Telecom Australia would seriously disadvantage the sick, elderly and disabled people as well as counselling and community services, particularly Lifeline.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Telecom Charges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The introduction of time-charging for local telephone calls by Telecom Australia would isolate many elderly and disabled people who depend on telephone services for communication and social contact.
That the greatest effect will be on isolated people and communities and will add to their disadvantages in that it will restrict social contact
The lifestyle of many people will be downgraded to facilitate business abuse of a technological device.

Totally reject plans by Telecom for time-charge local calls as a serious impost on housebound and isolated members of the community and the general public.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Telecom Charges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The introduction of time-charging for local telephone calls by Telecom Australia would seriously disadvantage thousands of elderly and disabled people and families, and would add a further burden to the already prohibitive cost of living borne by every Australian.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:

DEBATE.TITLE: RESIGNATION OF MEMBER FOR PARRAMATTA FROM MINISTRY

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: -Madam Speaker has received a letter from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The contempt shown to the Australian people by the Prime Minister and the Member for Parramatta through their failure to provide the Parliament with a full explanation of the facts surrounding the resignation of the Member for Parramatta from the Ministry.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The vote which has just been taken by this Parliament to deny to the Opposition its motion to move the suspension of Standing Orders makes this matter of public importance all the more relevant and all the more compelling. I remind the House that this matter of public importance once again gives to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and to the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr John Brown) an opportunity of coming into this Parliament and, unprotected by the forms of Question Time, explaining to this Parliament why it is that so far they have failed to give a convincing explanation of their roles in the World Expo 88 contract affair.

SPEECH.PARA: It would appear from those honourable members opposite who are present in the Parliament and by the way in which the Government has handled the matter to date, that once again the Prime Minister and the honourable member for Parramatta are going to treat the Parliament with contempt. I say to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, and to the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) that the Opposition warmly welcomes the opportunity of saying more about this particular affair.

We welcome the opportunity because once again it gives us the chance to remind the Australian public and this Parliament of the chapter of events which has unfolded. It gives us a chance to remind this Parliament once again that when it comes to questions of ministerial propriety it will always find the Prime Minister siding with mateship instead of duty. It gives us an opportunity to remind the Australian Parliament that although the honourable member for Parramatta resigned from the Ministry on 17 December less than two months after that the Prime Minister was talking about having him back in the Ministry. I suppose that is barely surprising because within six months of the former honourable member for Port Adelaide standing down from the Ministry for having leaked national security information in a Canberra car park, he was allowed back into the Ministry. So I suppose that the standard of the Hawke Government is six months if one endangers national security and less than three months if one misleads Parliament.

The level of contempt of this Government for ministerial standards and parliamentary propriety is not restricted to the Prime Minister and the honourable member for Parramatta. It goes right through the Government. A few minutes ago the Leader of the House, who, I might say, is a very poor man's imitation of Mick Young, came into the House and said to the Parliament, `The honourable member for Parramatta was forced to resign over a trivial matter'. A trivial matter to mislead the House! The Prime Minister goes running out of the Parliament. Even though at Question Time he challenged the Opposition to raise this matter by substantive motion what does he do? He scuttles and runs with his golfing partner, the honourable member for Parramatta. He leaves it to the Leader of the House and the poor disappointed honourable member for Maribyrnong (Mr Griffiths). I would have voted for the honourable member for Maribyrnong instead of Senator Bolkus too. It is no wonder that 10 members of the right wing deserted the Prime Minister. One can hardly expect the Prime Minister to have very good ministerial standards when he is prepared to vote for somebody like Senator Bolkus who is opposed to the American alliance; who is opposed to every decent defence and foreign policy instinct in the interests of this country. The Prime Minister is prepared to vote for Senator Bolkus instead of some honourable candidate, such as the honourable member for Kingston (Mr Bilney), put forward by the Centre Left. Yet that is what this great right wing Prime Minister did because of a factional deal. Oh, Andrew has joined us. I am delighted to see the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) join us. One day, because of a factional deal, we will have the Prime Minister voting for the honourable member for Calwell.
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —We will; I kid you not. If he will vote for Bolkus instead of Bilney, he will vote for Theophanous instead of Alan Griffiths. Mr Deputy Speaker, I digress a little from the substance of the motion. Let me return to it.
—You are going to have trouble filling in 15 minutes with this.

—If the Leader of the House thinks that, on this subject, I have to filibuster for 10 minutes, he is completely wrong. I renew the invitation to the Leader of the House, and issue it to the Prime Minister and to the honourable member for Parramatta, to go up into the Press gallery, knock on the door of News Ltd bureau-I do not know whether it has a door; not many of them do have doors-and say, `Can we listen to the tape?'. They will hear what the honourable member for Parramatta had to say during that interview and they will know that he said it with very great fervour. It was not hazy; it was not accidental; it was not mistaken; it was absolutely deliberate, and it was clearly reproduced on the front page of the Australian. What that interview did was to make it very plain that, far from the Prime Minister's heated denials of any kind of involvement in this issue, the Prime Minister was in it right up to his ears.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Parramatta must be the most hopelessly compromised member of parliament that we have seen in many years. The honourable member for Parramatta was forced to resign because he misled Parliament. I charge that he misled the Parliament deliberately-not accidentally and not technically. He has a perfect opportunity to come in here and demonstrate that what I am saying is wrong. But he will not do that; he will hide behind the cowardly device that the Government has adopted of denying to him or the Prime Minister an opportunity to give an account. Government members think it is very clever to use the Leader of the House to deny our motion. They thought they were very clever and sought to call on the matter of public importance, thinking there was no longer anything to be said about this. But what they have failed to understand is that this cowardly resort to silence by the honourable member for Parramatta and the Prime Minister is convincing nobody.

At Question Time today the Prime Minister failed to explain satisfactorily to the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown) the nature of the discussion that took place between the Prime Minister and the former Minister way back in April. The minute of 22 December from the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet to the Prime Minister, after the resignation of the Minister, pointed out, `Oh, Prime Minister, we may have said something to you a few weeks ago or a few days ago but we have subsequently learned that there were some exchanges between your office and perhaps you and the former Minister that we did not know about'. In other words, the Prime Minister's Department was covering its back; it was protecting its reputation. We still have not been told. The Prime Minister adopted the device that he so often adopts at Question Time when he gets an awkward question; he gives about one-third of the answer and then he goes off at a tangent and starts inviting people around to his office and talking about cappuccinos. All of those things are irrelevancies designed to lead the House into disinterest on the subject. But he did not answer the question put by the honourable member for Menzies and he did not answer the question put by my colleague the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock).

It is therefore not surprising that we have seen this extraordinary spectacle of this pathetically compromised former Minister, a man who the Prime Minister says has made a mountainous contribution to the tourism industry of Australia. I say that he has made a mountainous contribution to rewriting the rule books as they relate to ministerial conduct. I have never seen an example of a former Minister more hopelessly compromised. He did not resign because of any sense of honour or concern for the Parliament; that is the most sanctimonious nonsense that we have been treated to. He resigned because he was caught out. In the view of many of us on this side of the House, the document was leaked by a ministerial colleague. That is why he resigned. It had nothing to do with honour; it had nothing to do with concern for the Parliament. That is why he is not in here. That is why his seat is empty.

The honourable member for Parramatta is one of the most garrulous members we have ever seen. Certainly, if his performance, reported in the paper on Saturday morning, is any illustration, he has not ceased to be garrulous. But, on this issue, when his reputation and his credit are at stake-that is what he said to the Parliament-where is he? He is hiding for cover. He has run for cover. He has left it to the fall guys, such as they are-three of them-and they do not look very enthusiastic. They are in here trying to put up a miserable defence. But the honourable member is hopelessly compromised. He was caught out. He was sprung, probably by one of his own ministerial colleagues. Then, for a few fleeting hours, he thought he would be restored to the Ministry and, no doubt flushed with the expectation of that, went off and had a very long and revealing interview with a journalist from the Australian. A report of that interview turned up on the front page of the Weekend Australian on Saturday morning. What did he say in that interview? He said, `The Prime Minister shared my view; I was not alone'. Then he suddenly realised what he had done and pleaded, on bended knee, with the journalist, `Don't publish that; it might damage the Prime Minister. It is true, but don't publish it'. So, we have a new standard written for this Government: if anything that is true might damage the Prime Minister it must not be published. In other words, all the world can see the supreme cynicism of the Hawke Government splashed across the front page of the Weekend Australian on Saturday morning. I hope every student of ministerial standards and governmental propriety read it, because it was sickening in its cynicism. The honourable member did not ask that it not be published because it was wrong; he asked that it not be published because it might hurt the Prime Minister. The only reason he has changed his story now is that he does not want to do further damage to the Prime Minister.

There is no concern for the truth. We have not been told that the account in the Australian was wrong. We have not been told how such a detailed verbatim report can get into the newspapers. Everybody in this building knows that there is a tape recording available of the interview, and people can go and hear it in the offices of News Ltd if they like. I am correct in making that statement because I have verified it. But we were not told that. We were told only one simple thing: that it had to be withdrawn and that it must not be published because it might hurt the Prime Minister. That cynicism is sickening in the extreme.

We have had a lot of allegations lately about the Prime Minister losing touch. If we want another example of how this Prime Minister has lost touch, he has lost touch with the fact that at the end of the day nobody in politics in this country is so high and mighty that he is not accountable to the Parliament. The Prime Minister has lost touch with that reality. He thinks that he and anybody on whose shoulder he puts a hand-he certainly put his hand on John Brown's shoulder-is above all of that. He thinks that we should not bother great men with such trivial things, as the Leader of the House calls them, as an explanation to the Parliament as to why it was misled. I repeat-I will go on repeating it until we get a decent explanation from the Prime Minister and the former Minister-that this Parliament is the supreme body of this country. Ministers, whether Labor, Liberal or National Party, are accountable to the Parliament. No member or Prime Minister who thumbs his nose at the proprieties and the prerogatives of the Parliament can indefinitely walk tall and walk with the assurance that one would want in those positions. The Parliament has been treated shabbily; it has been treated contemptuously; and it has been treated thoroughly in keeping with the character and the behaviour of the Prime Minister over this issue. Members of the public have been treated shabbily; they have been misled; they have been treated arrogantly. We deserve better.
