SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) did make the full 15 minutes allotted to him. There was some suspicion on this side of the House that he might not do so, and when he got to the point of discussing the internal ballots for the Ministry in the Australian Labor Party (ALP), there was a degree of conviction that he was getting to a point where he might not be able to reach the 15 minutes.

SPEECH.PARA: To introduce that sort of topic in a discussion such as the one we are having here today begs the question of a discussion of his back bench, and who is and who ought not to be on it. It is a back bench replete with ex-Ministers-ex-Ministers who, in different degrees, were of good standing when they were Ministers. Yet we find them all now cooling their heels in the most faction-ridden Liberal Party that we have ever seen. There is a simple reason why most of them are sitting on the back bench. It has nothing to do with their talent; it is that they come from the wrong faction. We have on the back bench the honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee), the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown), the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) and one of the South Australian members-a whole range of former Ministers. Certainly, whether or not they were particularly talented Ministers, they are vastly more talented than the people who are sitting on the front bench of the Liberal Party. They have been left behind because of factional differences.

For any member of the Liberal Party to come into this House and tell members of the Labor Party that people are being justly or unjustly appointed to the front bench because of different positions they may have taken within groups within the Labor Party is simply yet another example-this whole debate has been replete with them-of an inability on the part of the Opposition to distinguish between pots and kettles when it comes to blackguarding the Government. Honourable members opposite themselves, in the purest case of psychological projection, attribute to us characteristics which are thoroughly common on their side of the House. The substance of this matter of public importance in that regard is no different at all.

The Leader of the Opposition might well like to come in hear and talk about Senator Bolkus. We will be happy to talk about his back bench any time he feels like imposing on us an obligation to discuss these matters. In addition to that consideration there are other elements of his lacklustre performance here in presenting his matter of public importance, his tired disinterested performance. Let us contrast the words about the greatest offences against parliamentary procedures possibly imaginable with the absence of passion in the way in which he proceeded with the presentation of his matter of public importance. We then get a real understanding of why this matter is not worthy of the consideration of the House.

The Leader of the Opposition does not believe a darned thing he says. He does not believe one thing that he has presented in this House. As to the notion that he has not had a full explanation, he has had a total and complete explanation from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). The fact that it has not produced reams and reams of material is simply a result of there not being reams and reams of material to produce. The honourable member for Parramatta (Mr John Brown) believed that, on that body that did the selection of the tender, two people voted who were not entitled to vote. He obviously believed that because he was so anxious to have one other member come forward and be consulted on the matter.

The Government had a different belief in that regard. What it believed was necessary in getting that additional point of view was a requirement that all artistic members of the board be consulted. That difference in perception led the honourable member for Parramatta inadvertently to mislead this House-no more than that. The facts of the matter, both as to the documents and the obvious logic of his behaviour, indicate that to be the case. I refer to the logic of his behaviour in seeking an extra vote and the facts of the matter as outlined in one of the memos which have gone through, which clearly indicated that the Minister had in his mind an erroneous interpretation of the situation, which was that the relevant public servants who were voting on that body were not entitled to a vote when, indeed, they were.

Far from being an example of a failure to uphold ministerial standards, which is what the Government stands accused of here, the honourable member for Parramatta took the ministerial standards to a point to which the Opposition was never prepared to go when it was in government, and probably beyond the point that we on this side of the House would regard as particularly appropriate. There has never been a requirement for a Minister to resign upon simply misleading the House. There has been a requirement for Ministers to resign when that misleading was deliberate. If one goes through the record of the previous Government, one finds numerous instances of Ministers being pulled up publicly and being obliged to change their lines on matters, in circumstances where the principal explanation given has been that they inadvertently misled the House and they now wish to correct their view. That is fine. In opposition in those days, we used to get up and make a few points ourselves when that type of situation occurred. We were prepared to use those issues in the cut and thrust of debate to make a few points about the Government, but the Government of the day-the Liberal-National Party Government-never took our points seriously enough to do anything about the Ministers concerned. That is fine. If, however, we apply the same standards to ourselves, we get a very different picture indeed.

So it was for high motives that the honourable member for Parramatta resigned. He did so, I believe, in a way which, most unfortunately for him, clouded what were his very real contributions to this country. The growing industry in this country has unquestionably been the tourism industry under his management. Australian sporting organisations benefited extraordinarily from his benevolent attention while he was the Minister of the day. I mentioned about eight ministerial resignations in my previous speech on this matter in speaking to the motion to suspend standing orders; I could have gone through something like 22. One thing was evident in all those cases: in none of them was there the public outpouring of support for the Minister who was placed in that position as there was when the honourable member for Parramatta resigned. The honourable member for Menzies and other honourable members on the other side of the House might have one view about the honourable member for Parramatta. The thousands of people, and the organisations representing thousands of people more, who sent telegrams to him on that occasion, have a totally different view.

If honourable members opposite want to say that they are in touch with this or that around the place, which they currently like to convey themselves as being, they should take note of that point. The Opposition in this chamber constitutes a motley crew of 50-odd people. The response, to which I have referred, to then Minister Brown's resignation came in from thousands. They took a different view of ministerial propriety than did the former Minister himself; they probably took the view that we on this side of the House would take in normal circumstances as to what was an appropriate course of action.

It is sneered that the Prime Minister at some future date, although no undertaking has been given, might contemplate the return of the honourable member for Parramatta to the Ministry; yet the gravamen of those many communications was that he ought to be returned immediately. That was the suggestion put forward by them. Let us consider the question of returns to the front bench and the view that people have to be placed in purgatory for ever in this place once they have come in here and made a mistake. Thankfully for the Opposition, the standard it attempts to impose on us it does not impose on itself. Whilst it is making very little use of the talented ex-Ministers on its back benches, I know of at least one it has permitted on its front bench-an ex-Minister who resigned in similar circumstances-and that is the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore). We do not dispute the right of the honourable member for Ryan to be there. We simply require the Opposition to apply the same standards to us when it preaches at us. Despite the many virtues of the honourable member for Ryan, his resignation certainly was not accompanied by that public outpouring of support that was given to the honourable member for Parramatta.

As I said, the Prime Minister has made quite clear in this place his views on what were the facts of the matter, not only at dispute in previous days but also contained in the Press over the weekend. Even though there has been a full public statement, both in public and in this place in Question Time, as to all the relevant facts involved, again the Opposition comes at us with a second set of double standards. There is the double standard on the issue of the circumstances in which ministerial statements ought to be made to Parliament. The Opposition in its Press release today and in this House has waxed eloquent on the absolute requirement for Ministers upon resignation to make statements here. But when we look at the record of the Opposition in this regard, again we see a mixed response. Vic Garland resigned on the issue of electoral bribery; no statement. Phil Lynch resigned over allegations that he had received special consideration in profitable land deals in 1976; no ministerial statement and, incidentally, no bar on his subsequent return to the Ministry. There were no problems there. That is fine.

TALK.START.PARA: —There was an inquiry.

—But there was no statement to Parliament on that occasion. Senator Glen Sheil resigned over pro-apartheid statements; no statement to Parliament. We had the very celebrated case of Senator Reg Withers-no-one could accuse the Right Honourable Reg Withers of being a taciturn man-when he was dismissed as Minister for Administrative Services on allegations of impropriety. There was a short statement from Carrick but there was no debate and no statement from the senator from Western Australia. There were other occasions on which there were statements, but when we sit down to look at this we have to say that if there is an absolute requirement on all of these subjects, that absolute requirement has not been conformed to by the Opposition. We had the famous case of the then Minister for Finance-the week-long resignation and readmission for which no explanation was ever given in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: What have we seen in the last week since the Parliament has been in session? We saw the Opposition charge into this place, telling the Press, telling everybody who was prepared to listen, how it would do over the Government on the subject of its alleged losing touch with its base; how it was going to make the Government stand on its head over the management of economic policy; how it was going to censure us on issues of ministerial propriety. But what have we seen in the past week and a bit? We have seen dribs and drabs, footling here, footling there. None of the issues of the day have been considered. None of the very significant matters that ought to be of concern to this Parliament have been considered. We have heard only a constant pleading for the Government to tell the Opposition something other than what the Government has repeatedly told it and which was borne out by the facts of this matter. It has pleaded with the Government to say more on something about which there is nothing to say. The Opposition has had its matter of public importance on the matter. It has made an effort to suspend Standing Orders on the matter. There is nothing more to say, and the spokesmen for the Opposition have demonstrated that amply.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the comparative calm in this debate on the matter of public importance it is probably very suitable and appropriate to begin by asking the question: why are we concerned about the involvement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in this whole matter concerning the contract for a $5m theatre in the Australian pavilion at World Expo 88? The answer is very simple, but to understand the answer we have to explain how this issue arose. The case against the former Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr John Brown), was simply that in the case of a tendering process for a quite substantial Commonwealth job the Minister had interfered in the tendering process. Despite the fact that the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley), for reasons best known to himself, has come out with this extraordinary proposition that it does not matter whether the Minister interferes in a tendering process, the fact is that some of us who work within this parliamentary system regard it as being traditionally very wrong and very bad if a Minister, having set up a tender panel, then seeks to impose his own will on the decision that that body might make.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Leader of the House wants to do some research on this subject he need go back no further than a debate we had in November in this House concerning the Amann contract, the coastwatch contract. In that case the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris), the then Minister for Transport, although he has reappeared as Minister for Transport and Communications Support, having been somewhat demoted, stated the principle in a way with which I believe no one disagrees. The Minister said on that occasion that if a Minister were found to be involved up to the elbows in a tendering process, trying to twist and contort things so he got out of the tendering process the result he wanted, that would be reprehensible and he would be deserving of censure.

It is exactly that case the Minister portrayed that we have here. We started off, therefore, with the case against the honourable member for Parramatta that he had interfered in the tendering process and that that was reprehensible. We said that he had interfered in it twice. The first occasion was when the American company Bob Rogers and Co. was given the contract in the first place. We said also that he had interfered on a second occasion. The Government had set up a tender assessment panel to go through the whole wretched thing again. It had come out with a report. It had delivered that report and given it to the then Minister. The report said, `Give this contract to the Australian company AAV'. But the then Minister would not accept that. What we said against him was that he again interfered in the tendering process by holding back the decision and trying to get a different result out of the process than the one that had been produced.

We said in support of that, `Look what he did. He took the tender assessment panel report and said, ``That's no good. I don't accept that result. Go back and do it again'', in an attempt to get the result that he wanted'. That is what the allegation was. The Minister replied, `No. It's true that I asked the tender assessment panel to go over the thing a second time, but I didn't do that to twist and contort it so that I could get the result I wanted. I did it for a very simple and understandable reason; that is, that the panel had not given me a clear recommendation. They had not done that. They just gave me a 50:50 split decision. I didn't know where I was. Was I expected to toss a coin? What did you expect me to do? I just sent it back to them and asked them to do it again'.

Now, we know that he misled the Parliament when he said that because he was sprung by the Sydney Morning Herald, and I believe sprung by a Minister in the Hawke Government, who leaked that document to that newspaper. The result is that his spurious excuse was seen for exactly what it was, completely transparent. If the excuse is as transparent as it obviously is, we are left, are we not, with the conclusion I put in the first place, which is that he was interfering in the tender process and was trying to contort the results that that body came up with in an endeavour-still, at that late hour-to get this valuable contract for the American company.

That, then, is the context we are working in. That is how the issue arises. That is how the issue comes to be before the Parliament. That is why it continues to preoccupy the Press and it occupies our minds. It now seems to be the object of such a fetish with the Government that even it cannot leave it alone. The Government defeated our motion to suspend the Standing and Sessional Orders only half an hour ago. Now it has given us the opportunity to raise the issue again and to pursue it even further for reasons that completely escape me. Nevertheless, here we go. At this late stage, over the weekend, the Government itself reopened the issue. We did not reopen it, the Government did. The Government reopened it via the former Minister who gave a foolish interview to the Australian which was published on Saturday in that newspaper.

What has the honourable member for Parramatta done now? He has embroiled the Prime Minister in this very issue. Frankly, I am at such a stage of confusion that I do not know which of them to believe. There are so many allegations and counter-allegations flying around that it is almost impossible to make any rational assessment of what either of them believes. But out of that morass, that mess, I believe we can come to two clear conclusions and those conclusions are the basis on which we say that this House is entitled to a full explanation from both of them. We know that just as both the Prime Minister and the former Minister refused to speak before, likewise they are refusing to speak in this debate on a matter of public importance.

As I said, there are two conclusions. The first conclusion is that by a Minister resigning and no statement being made in the Parliament-in this House or the Senate-either by the Prime Minister or the former Minister as to why he resigned, the Parliament has been treated with contempt. The Leader of the House-where are you now Michael Jerome Young when we really need you-trotted out a few other cases of Ministers who resigned where no statement was made to the Parliament. He says that that is the justification for no statement being made here. Let me remind him about the case of Senator Withers, which was one of the cases that he relied on. There was a royal commission into that matter; there was a thorough investigation of the case. There were court cases about at least one of the matters he raised.

What we are faced with here is a Minister who has resigned. No explanation has been given to the Parliament despite the fact that the documents that have been released show clearly that the Prime Minister was involved, whereas he says he was not. That is why there is a contentious issue. That is why we are entitled to a statement in this place. The documents say that the Prime Minister was involved. There are five of those documents, some of which have been referred to in the House already. A document prepared by Mr Lleonart in the Minister's former Department says that the whole issue of the voting entitlements of the public servants was cleared with the Prime Minister's office. Another document which has so far not been referred to in this House and which I got under the Freedom of Information Act, tells us that this issue was coming up. It says:
. . . suggested that the Prime Minister ask Mr Brown for a report on the current situation on the Australian pavilion.

Honourable members can see that there is a blank under that statement. Material was taken out before the document was released under the Freedom of Information Act. We do not know what the Cabinet decided on this very issue. Let me tell honourable members that I have appealed against this exclusion from the document which relates to a very relevant matter on a very relevant date-10 April. My appeal has been rejected by people in the Prime Minister's own Department. What are they hiding? This issue was before the Cabinet. Bits have been taken out of a document so that we will not know what was going on. When I appealed against that, they rejected my appeal and said, `You can go whistle for it'? What are they hiding? They have refused us hundreds of documents under the Freedom of Information Act. Why are they hiding those documents?

Time prevents me from going into all of the documents. But they all show that the Prime Minister was involved. He had actual knowledge of the very issue which led to the Minister's resignation. That is the reason why we, the Parliament and the public, are entitled to a statement from these two people who refused to debate this matter in a censure motion and who now refuse even to take part today in a debate of a matter of public importance. What are they hiding? We would like to know. We and the Press will continue to pursue this issue until we find out. This former Minister has presided over a complete shambles in public administration. The Government has engaged in deception from beginning to end. What do we have at the end of the day? We have a claim by an American company, which the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) wrote to me about the other day and, believe it or not Mr Deputy Speaker, said, `I understand we will have to give up and admit liability'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Griffiths Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The one compelling and accurate contribution made by the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown) was when he said, `I am so confused, I do not know what to believe any more'. The filibuster that the Opposition has engaged in is simply that-a filibuster. Not one skerrick of new evidence or new information has been put before the House this afternoon. We have had a tedious repetition of issues that have been covered, recovered and covered again. Those matters have been addressed exhaustively not only on previous occasions in this House, but also during Question Time and in the context of the debate on the proposed suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders. It really is quite difficult from my point of view to come into the debate at this point and add anything new.

SPEECH.PARA: The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) affected his most statesmanlike pose. He referred to this debate as one that was relevant and compelling. He went on, of course, to filibuster about ministerial vacancies in the Hawke Labor Government. He was kind enough to acknowledge my potential for one of those vacancies. I might add that in so doing, he probably gave me the kiss of death. The Opposition could have brought this matter before the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr John Brown) by way of censure motion. But it did not have the courage to do so. I ask why not? If all the rhetoric that the Opposition has put before the House in the last few minutes is of substance, the appropriate way to go about that matter is by censure motion. The Opposition does not have the courage to do that, and that ought to be put in some context. The Opposition has a history in this chamber of spreading censure motions around like confetti. One need only recall some of the irrelevant issues that it embraced by way of censure motion to gain a real assessment of how important the Opposition perceives this issue to be.

Of course, the honourable member for Menzies, after having been demoted almost into the corridor, has latched on to this issue-and good luck to him-as his way back on to the front bench. My guess is that he will get there because of the publicity that he has generated around this issue. But he is not prepared to let it go and that to me shows a most uncharitable and vindictive streak in the honourable member for Menzies. I find that this streak comes through in many of his contributions in this House.

A Minister has resigned from the Cabinet on the issue of misleading Parliament. In my view that was not required. Because this happened on the last day of Parliament, there was not the opportunity to clarify the matters that he had put before the Parliament. It is a matter of record, and is accepted by everyone in this chamber, that a Minister must answer to the Parliament by resigning for a deliberate misleading of the House. Nothing that the Opposition has put before the House would enable the construction of a case for the sacking of the then Minister in relation to this issue.

The contribution that the honourable member for Parramatta has made to this House has been adequately canvassed. I will not add anything to that, except to say that I think most members of this House, when they were outside the politics of this chamber, would acknowledge the very real contribution that the then Minister made in his portfolio. As I have indicated, I think it is a particularly insensitive and uncharitable approach for the Opposition not only to pursue the resignation, which in political terms is an execution, but also to try to engage in something more like a sentence to hang, draw and quarter someone who has made a mistake in this chamber. I believe that most people who have even a rudimentary knowledge of the merits or otherwise of this case will accept that the sanction-that is, the resignation of a Cabinet Minister-is as far as one can go, in all decency, or aspire to from the Opposition's point of view.

If Opposition members are to demand not only the hanging but also the drawing and quartering of someone who has not deliberately misled the House but who has acknowledged misleading the House, one ought to be able-notwithstanding the time difference-to reflect on how they embraced those issues when they were in government. Their behaviour compared with ours is like chalk and cheese. A moment ago reference was made to Senator Withers and the circumstances in which he found himself involved. The honourable member for Menzies made the point, appropriately, that those matters were subject to a royal commission. They were subjected to a royal commission because they were of the utmost import. They implied a deliberate misleading of the House and they went to the heart of the democratic process in this country. Those allegations were none other than an attempt to rort the electoral boundaries upon which the government of this nation would be based.

Those matters were of enormous import. They went to a deliberate misleading of the House. They were nothing to do with a contract where a body existed to look at particular tenders and where in any event the outcome of that process would be placed before the Cabinet. The Cabinet was going to weigh the issues, take into account the advice of the committee and then, as is its responsibility, make a judgment as to what it considered to be in the best interests of this country. As has been said on previous occasions, the Cabinet is not bound to accept the lowest tender in such matters. It is not bound by some of the imputed arguments put forward by the Opposition. It is bound by that one and most compelling criterion-to take into account all the matters put before it and to make its judgment as to what it perceives to be in the best interests of this country.

In the final analysis, all this rot about how many members on the committee voted one way or the other is just that. The material was sufficient to have the Minister resign for what he considered to be an inadvertent misleading of Parliament. So to that extent it was important, but it ought not to be blown out of all proportion. It ought not be grist for an argument that the issues go right to the heart of the Cabinet as it now is. That is just utter rot.

When one goes over the previous Government's record, as has been canvassed briefly in this House, it is instructive to go through not only the number of Ministers who have resigned in unfortunate circumstances-to put it very kindly-but also the range of issues in which they were involved. I do not want to drag into this House the names of people who are no longer members of Parliament and I shall not do so. However, let me put it this way: there were some 22 resignations, either forced or otherwise, during the seven years of the Fraser Government. Against that our record stands very well. However, our record stands up even more when one takes into account the quality, or the severity, of the issues involved in those circumstances. I have already indicated one-the old toecutter. He has dished it out in his day and I am sure that he would not mind my referring to him in that way. The issues involved not who got a relatively minor contract, on which Cabinet would make the final decision in any event; they were matters that went to the heart of how this Parliament and the Government ought to conduct their affairs. They went, in crude terms, to the rorting of Federal electorate boundaries for the purpose of achieving an advantage for a particular political party. No-one on either side of this chamber would have the temerity to argue that those matters were not of great import.

I could go chapter and verse through all those resignations. I am constrained from doing so because I think that it is inappropriate, given that some of those involved are no longer members of this place and do not have an opportunity to answer. I conclude on this note: the Minister resigned for misleading Parliament. He did not resign for deliberately misleading Parliament. If that is the sanction that is required of anyone who comes into this chamber, those hypocrites opposite ought to come in and canvass all the misleading of Parliament that their colleagues and they no doubt did in their time in government.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 February, on motion by Mr Duncan:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
upon which Mr Blunt had moved by way of amendment:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: `whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House:

(1) condemns the Government for its lack of action to date in abolishing a number of government-imposed constraints on Australia Post, Telecom Australia and the Overseas Telecommunications Commission including:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —In continuation of my remarks last Thursday, I will summarise the effect of the Communications Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2). The final paragraph of the Opposition's amendment mentions privatisation. Last Thursday I reminded the House that customers have far from benefited from privatisation and deregulation in other countries. I instanced the doubling of public telephone charges, the ending of free emergency repairs, the removal of exchanges, far higher payouts by both business and residential customers, chaotic services and poor country services in countries in which privatisation and deregulation have taken place. I urge the Opposition to join the Government in its caution in proceeding towards privatisation and deregulation.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendment mentions a number of industrial issues. I wish to make a few points in that respect because I feel that the Opposition is trying to take us to the position of British Telecom which has seen widespread problems for customers and widespread hazards for staff. There has been a reduction in resources devoted to safety in Britain. At national levels staff numbers in British Telecom's safety division have been cut. The union safety representatives who are appointed are not being trained within the six months specified in the relevant agreement. Most seriously of all, the accident situation in British Telecom is worse now than it has been for many years. Accidents now total 16,000 a year at a cost of some #6.5m. The first year of privatisation, 1985, was particularly bad. After four years with no fatal accidents, four employees were killed at work. It was the worst year for deaths since 1974. In the same year, British Telecom was twice prosecuted successfully by the Health and Safety Executive for breaches of the health and safety at work legislation. That is nothing like the outstanding record of British Telecom before privatisation, nor is it like the outstanding record of Telecom Australia.

The amendment goes on to talk about the superannuation regime. I remind the Opposition that the existing British Telecom pension scheme will not apply to new employees. Instead, they will have to join a new, significantly worse scheme. The new scheme will provide them with less valuable benefits. British Telecom has never been able to justify this move. The move will cost the firm precisely the same amount of money. Now British Telecom admits that that was done only to bring its pension scheme down to the level of the private sector. With regard to staffing, pay, conditions and pensions it is clear to staff in Australia that the privatisation of British Telecom was bad news there.

This Bill will streamline the contract procedures for the delightfully successful and very efficient Overseas Telecommunications Commission (OTC)-a world leader in communication-and for the other great participants in Australia's development: Australia Post and Telecom. Today we need to allow more freedom to OTC, Telecom and Australia Post to enter into a hedging contract as soon as a trading contract is negotiated. This legislation will enable that. By removing the obligation to require securities issued by Australia Post and Telecom to be guaranteed by the Commonwealth, it will enable services to become more flexible. When honourable members vote on this Bill they will make an economically and socially sound decision to reduce the risk of dangerous goods, in conjunction with comprehensive preventative programs worked out by Australia Post with the unions. In the increasing complexity of radio communications this Bill will ensure that manufacturers will able to obtain certification that the equipment they are about to place on the market has no undesirable effect on radio communications. That, of course, is much better than finding that out later.

Other changes to be made by the Bill will include the practice of type testing of radio communications equipment being placed on a statutory basis. Further, the Bill will provide a statutory power to prohibit the supply or operation, or possession for the purposes of supply or operation, of devices intended to cause interference with the legitimate use of the radio frequency spectrum; or likely to cause interference with radio communications in such a way as to endanger life or property.

The Bill represents further evidence of the Government's commitment to efficiency and sound commercial practice for major government business enterprises such as OTC, Australia Post and Telecom. It is significant that the first honourable member for Eden-Monaro, in 1901, Austin Chapman, became Postmaster-General during his parliamentary term. He was one of the pioneers of the great communications services that have contributed much to the development of our nation. Now this Bill will take into account the safety of Australia Post employees, and legitimate users of postal services, with regard to the efficient and equitable use of the radio frequency spectrum, which is a scarce and valuable resource. I am pleased to support the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I disagree entirely with what the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) has said about this Bill being an example of the Government's commitment to a prosperous and efficient statutory enterprise, or set of statutory enterprises. SPEECH.PARA: I direct my remarks to two main parts of the Bill: allowance of various communications bodies to enter into hedging contracts; and removal of the need for compulsory government guarantees for certain borrowings. The sense in which I have said that the Bill is welcomed is that it provides greater freedom and flexibility for Telecom, the Overseas Telecommunications Commission (OTC) and Australia Post with regard to some of their financial affairs and administrative arrangements. However, these measures are belated. For the last several years those bodies have been asking the Government for these very powers-but they do not go far enough. OTC in particular frequently has requested the ability to enter into hedging contracts in order to minimise the risk of changing exchange rates and future prices. When the Government floated the exchange rate it was necessary for those authorities that have to borrow overseas to have the authority to indemnify themselves against violent fluctuations in the Australian dollar-or in whatever currency they were borrowing. It is a great shame that it has taken such a long time for business enterprises as important to the economy of this country as OTC and Telecom to be granted the right to indemnify themselves.

I should be interested to know how much money OTC has lost as a result of its exposure to fluctuating exchange rates that were introduced by this Government, and price rises since then. That would reflect just how belated indeed this measure is. Welcome, though belated, as this measure is, it touches only the surface of the problems experienced by the Australian communication authorities covered by this Bill. Instead of proposing this omnibus Bill of unrelated amendments to various Acts of this Parliament, I should have thought that the Government would have worked hard at stripping away the costly, outmoded, and burdensome rules and petty regulations that, for a number of years, have saddled Telecom, OTC and Australia Post.

The Government promised those authorities that it would do precisely what the honourable member for Eden-Monaro claimed the Bill does, that is, enable them to operate as efficient managers in public statutory authorities. However, it still has not done that. On the contrary, some time ago the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) proposed a Green Paper which would have done the reverse; far from making them more independent, self-managed, and able to meet the obligations that individual statutes of Parliament imposed on their board of directors, it would have been more intrusive and made them more accountable to the Department of Finance, the Department of Administrative Services, the Crown Solicitor, and various other bodies to whom they are now obliged to report. Even in the most petty matters that do not involve large sums of money, compared with the turnover of those enterprises, they have had to report as though they were still members of the Postmaster-General's Department. They have been hamstrung by meddling delays of petty bureaucratic procedures, instead of being given freedom to move. They certainly have not been given scope to be as efficient as they want to be. On the contrary, Senator Walsh, in his Green Paper, at least intended to impose more burdens upon them.

When the Green Paper was released it was rightly ridiculed by all parties, except of course Senator Walsh's Department of Finance. Seminars were held around Australia, at which the chairmen of the various boards made public their views. At the time there were even rumours that the boards of those authorities had threatened to resign if the bureaucratic intervention was increased.

At the same time that this debate took place-and it continued for a long time, during which Senator Walsh's paper was rewritten several times-the Government, in a succession of Budgets and mini-Budgets, was milking these profitable authorities, especially OTC and Telecom, under the guise of imposing new sales taxes, and putting up interest rates or asking for repayment of capital funds in an arbitrary fashion. Certainly some moneys are owed. However, the management of those bodies had planned on the basis of arrangements entered into legally with the Government when they were created in 1975. In fairness it should be said that the previous Government also was guilty of that. Though this Government claims not to do those things it has set about time and again, in each Budget and mini-Budget, milking these profitable authorities. The result is that they have had less to invest in capital investment, research and development unless they borrowed.

That brings me back to one aspect of the Bill. When the authorities borrowed, they were not able to hedge their debts. Another aspect is that when they borrowed they did so allegedly with a government guarantee, which might have given them a rate of interest marginally better than that available in the private sector. That advantage has been taken away. As a result, when they borrow now they do so at a rate of interest higher than previously, thus increasing their indebtedness as well as the national indebtedness, and increasing the price to the consumer. The Government has shown no signs of removing the administrative and costly burdens that it imposes on those authorities, and no signs of removing its temptation to milk them. When we come to the mini-Budget in May we will find again that another impost, over and above that which has been contracted, will be imposed on these organisations. I believe the reason why Telecom Australia started a program for introducing locally timed calls was really a game of bluff with the Government with a view to trying to minimise the damage that would be done in the forthcoming May statement. Telecom would never have believed that the Prime Minister would have actually endorsed the arrangements, but he did so and we know what happened subsequently. This has been the pattern.

Despite all the debates engendered by the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, who is the appropriate Minister, and all the discussions taking place publicly and privately between the two authorities and the Government, the Bill is silent and no attention has been paid to these vexed matters which bear heavily on the organisations' capacity to be efficient. They are efficient within the ambit allowed by the Government but they could be even more efficient, and again one wonders about the hidden agenda. When the Green Paper was released in 1986, the respected economic journalist Maximilian Walsh called it a hidden agenda. He said:

While the politicians hold party conferences and map out grand strategies, there is a power game being played within the bureaucracy. Ever so rarely a window opens . . . It was this prospect which drew me back to the Green Paper of the proposed policy guidelines for statutory authorities and Government business enterprises. To ensure that it did nothing to disturb the politicians, it was tabled on 6 June with comment being invited over the following months; three months which included the ALP National Conference, the Liberal Federal Council and the most controversial budget in half a century.

I believe that that comment was undeniably correct. I remember the former Minister for Communications, Mr Duffy, and I having debates on that issue in this House and both of us regretting the way in which a succession of Budgets had milked these organisations. Nothing in this Bill cures that and we have no assurance that it will be cured. Although Senator Walsh has had to back away from many of the things he put in his Green Paper now that he has produced his White Paper, he is still imposing many burdens on these organisations. Again, if one becomes a little conspiratorial, one has to ask: what is the hidden agenda? Why is the Government not doing the very thing that the honourable member for Eden-Monaro just claimed it is doing? Why is the Government putting obstacles in the way of efficiency in these organisations? Does it want to run them down to the extent where the only real alternative is to privatise them, flog them off, and flog them off at relatively bargain basement prices-the very criticism that the honourable member for Eden-Monaro made of the British Telecom sale? If this is done which stockbrokers will get the work? Will it be the Whitlam Turnbull group, Rene Rivkin or John Singleton? These are the people-friends of the Government-who are likely to be purchasers and beneficiaries of commissions if this privatisation of a run-down organisation goes ahead.

Since this Government came to power, OTC has paid around 70 per cent of its net profits to the Federal Government, whereas other commercial companies have paid around 39 per cent. Telecom has paid 50.5 per cent whereas its communications counterparts in Japan and Canada have paid only 11.6 per cent and 12.5 per cent respectively. By the end of the 1980s Telecom, Australia Post and OTC will pay nearly $1 billion between them to the Government. Yet in 1986 the Government was advised that there was already a $300m shortfall in the telecommunications capital works program, with a 10 to 15 per cent increase needed over the next few years to keep pace with demand for technological developments. We know how critical the development of telecommunications is in Australia-a country so far from anywhere and needing communications across two huge oceans. Australia simply cannot afford to have any barriers put in the way of research and development and the purchase and installation of new infra- structure. Yet this Government, particularly, has placed barriers in that way and nothing in this Bill does anything to improve that situation. So the Government cannot claim for itself what the honourable member for Eden-Monaro has just claimed.

In fact, this is not a Bill that rectifies the areas where there is now insufficient competition in value-added services in telecommunications. For five years the Government has baulked at subjecting Telecom to greater competition. Telecom is well and truly prepared-administratively and psychologically-for these challenges. The Government has prevented competition in the installation and maintenance area and it does not subject Telecom to the Trade Practices Act. What reforms has the Government in fact introduced? This Bill is peripheral to what is really needed-that is, a much more adventurous examination of the way in which value-added services are provided on the main network provided by OTC or Telecom. After this Bill and the White Paper have been introduced, sadly I find still relevant my remarks made on the Green Paper on 4 September 1986 to a graduate school of management seminar at Sydney University. On that occasion I said:

In the first five years of this decade, OTC paid taxes and dividends to the Commonwealth totalling $238m leaving only $55m with which to finance essential government works program. Over that time, OTC paid 76 per cent of its net profits to the Federal Government whereas companies listed on the Sydney Stock Exchange paid out only 39 per cent over the same period. The payout ratio for Telecom was not much better, being 50.5 per cent in the same period that BHP paid out 32.8 per cent of net profits in dividends and taxes. Telecom's counterparts in Canada and Japan paid 12.5 per cent and 11.6 per cent respectively. In the last financial year, Telecom, OTC and Australia Post paid around $800m between them to the Federal Government and this year, as a result of the Budget, the figure will be even higher.

That is a sad indictment of the Government. It commissioned a report by Dr Henry Ergas, who pointed out very clearly what was needed, in terms of Australia's well-being, for investment in telecommunications. In fact, the Ergas report said that there was that $300m shortfall to which I referred and that we needed to increase our investment by some 10 per cent to 15 per cent to keep up with world trends. Being starved of funds and having a regime of external controls imposed upon their programming requirements-which is what the Minister for Finance wanted-the authorities would have found more inhibition on them to do what is demonstrably needed in terms of our interests. The fact is that there is a knowledge-intensive appetite in Australia. If we are to be competitive on world markets, we have to move into those activities which use the services provided by improved and sophisticated technological communications equipment. If we are to export substantially and be a big export earner, it must be in areas which are knowledge related-value-added technology services, information services and the like. It is very sad that a country which is now seeing the demise of much of its manufacturing, has seen the decline of a lot of its rural industries and is seeing difficulties with its tourism-a fickle industry to rely upon-is not taking any steps to move into these knowledge-based industries and give the freedom that should be given to Telecom and particularly to OTC.

I return to my disappointment about this Bill. What does it really do? It belatedly enables the authorities to hedge contracts in the event of there being wild fluctuations in the exchange rate-that is good but it is too late. In removing the need for compulsory government guarantees for certain borrowings, the Government has kowtowed to certain views expressed frequently by financiers and by certain members of the private sector. But it does not matter very much, in practice, whether government guarantees are given to a statutory authority. Interest rates may be slightly lower if the government guarantee is given. Does anyone seriously think that, firstly, Telecom or OTC would go broke or, secondly, that any Australian government would allow them to? Of course not. It is inconceivable that an Australian government would welsh on the debts incurred legitimately in accordance with the law of this country by the boards of Telecom or OTC.

In those circumstances this Bill does not mean much except that it is a gesture of the private sector to say that it will borrow on the same terms. For those on marginally higher interest rates it worsens their indebtedness and their capacity to invest more without charging their consumers more. In the process it slightly increases our own national debt and does nothing whatever to rectify the administrative problems which would make providers of those services more efficient which every one of our productive industries requires. Therefore, while welcoming the Bill with qualifications, I put that challenge to the Government. Much more remains to be done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee Mr M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Communications Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) and to oppose the Opposition's amendment. I always enjoy listening to the honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee) because he always puts forward his sincerely held views honestly and frankly. Naturally, I do not always agree with the comments he makes in this chamber and outside. I was certainly very interested in his comments that perhaps the Government has listened too much to some people in private enterprise in regard to the changes which this Bill proposes to implement.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I take issue with his suggestion that the Government is milking government enterprises to such an extent that it intends to sell off these great government operations and that perhaps stockbroking companies such as Whitlam Turnbull-of course, Turnbull is a former candidate for Liberal Party of Australia preselection in the seat of Wentworth-Rene Rivkin, John Singleton or perhaps other stock exchange companies are going to profit as a result of some future Government decision. I doubt that the honourable member has any evidence for those claims. If he had I am sure that he would have produced and tabled it in the House. It does the House no credit to make those sorts of allegations when, in fact, he is stating something which is, in the end, a figment of his imagination. I do not think it is fair to the people whom he has named.

It is most important for us to realise what the legislation does. As the honourable member for Goldstein pointed out, it allows Telecom Australia, the Overseas Telecommunications Commission and Australia Post to enter into hedging contracts. That allows those government bodies to be put on a more commercial basis. I think that is good for the organisations concerned. Of course, since the Government took the historic decision to float the Australian dollar and allow the market to set an appropriate level we have seen it fluctuate day to day and week to week as Australia's economic conditions have changed. Whilst that introduces an element of instability into the Australian economy I think that almost all economic commentators accept that on the whole that has been good for Australia. Our dollar has risen and fallen to its natural level. However, because of that instability it is very important that government enterprises be able to enter into hedging contracts so that like private enterprises they can cover themselves for any wild fluctuations that occur in the exchange rate.

One issue of crucial importance to Telecom which has received a lot of attention in recent days relates to the Telecom proposal to introduce time charged local telephone calls. The previous speaker, the honourable member for Goldstein, mentioned Dr Henry Ergas and the Ergas report on Telecommunications and the Australian Economy. I understand that that report went some way in advocating the introduction of time charged local telephone calls. Certainly, in an article in the Australian Financial Review Dr Ergas appeared to me to be quite supportive of the position that time charged local calls would be worthwhile. In addition, the Opposition shadow Minister for communications, the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt), made the following comments in his speech during the second reading debate on the Bill. He said:

I reflect for a moment on the way in which the Government handled the time charging of telephone calls in recent weeks. That was a commercial decision taken by a Government enterprise. The Minister said that the Government believes in efficiency and sound commercial enterprise, yet the Government has been running away from the policy when the acid is actually put on it, when Telecom decides that it wants to be commercial and take the decisions that a business enterprise would take in terms of setting its prices the way it charges for its product.

I wish to know whether the shadow Minister is saying-this is what I believe he is saying-that if Telecom takes a decision this Government must be bound to implement it. If so, I take issue with that attitude to Telecom. I think that it is commendable that this Government, after a few weeks of debate on the issue, took the decision to tell Telecom that time charged local calls were simply not on. If the shadow Minister for communications thinks that it is wrong for the Government to overrule Telecom and say that it cannot introduce time charged local calls, I shudder to think what will happen if one day he ends up the Minister responsible for communications.

From the comments of the honourable member for Richmond in his speech to the second reading of the Bill it appears quite clear that he supports time charged local calls. Given that he comes from north-eastern New South Wales, I suspect that he and, perhaps, other members of the National Party of Australia rural rump have no difficulties at all with time charged local calls.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are already paying them under your Government; that is why.

—The honourable member for Maranoa, by his interjection, also indicates that he supports the introduction of time charged local calls because a number of constituents in his electorate already pay for calls by time. Is he saying that everyone now has to pay for time charged local calls? Obviously, it is quite clear that the agenda of the National Party is to bring in time charged local calls for all Australians. I am very proud of the fact that this Government has told Telecom to pull its head in and will not be introducing time charged local calls. Any government which sought to bring in time charged local calls would be introducing an economic weapon which would severely disadvantage Australians, particularly the elderly and people who are isolated who depend to a very great degree on the telephone for communication with the outside world.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish also to comment on the fact that Telecom has argued that it is necessary to bring in time charged local telephone calls because of the introduction of new technology. Telecom has argued that the increasing use of facsimile machines and slave computer terminals has meant that a large number of telephone lines have been clogged up and that, as a result, it is necessary to bring in time charging for local calls. That is a point of view which the National Party appears to be supporting. I would argue that fax machines do not clog up the telephone network. Most people who send a fax message send a couple of pages. The fax machine dials the number, the document is sent and the fax machine terminates the call because one does not know when a fax will be received. It is very important the the line be kept open. Fax machines are not clogging up the system. That is not true.

I admit that there are a number of cases in which computers and some of the electronic funds transfer at point of sale machines, the EFTPOS machines, can sit on a local telephone line and clog up the system. I believe that if that is a significant problem for Telecom and its network it should look at some way of slugging the people who are manipulating the system and exploiting the fact that there is no time charge on local calls. Telecom should be smart enough to work out a way to slug those people rather than introducing time charging for every one of the five million subscribers in Australia. That is something which I and my colleagues, such as the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price), will continue to oppose tooth and nail.

This legislation also introduces some changes to the Postal Services Act. At the moment the Act prohibits the sending of dangerous goods through the post. Honourable members will be aware that in January last year some explosive material injured a postal worker at the Brisbane Mail Exchange-something which I am sure everyone in this House regrets very deeply. I understand that since then a training program has been introduced for staff who are responsible for handling Australia Post parcels. This legislation proposes to amend the Postal Services Act so that the sending of explosives and other prescribed dangerous goods is prohibited. In fact, the new penalties for sending explosives through the mail will be up to 10 years in gaol and/or a $20,000 fine. That is something which I support wholeheartedly.

The legislation also amends the Radiocommunications Act. I am very interested in clause 16 of the Bill, which provides for the Minister to ban devices which interfere, disrupt or disturb radiocommunications. I assume the intention is to ban devices which may seek to jam or interfere with other radio traffic. I am sure you, Mr Deputy Speaker, will have had constituents contact you with complaints that people using citizen band (CB) devices are interfering with their television reception or other radiocommunications equipment. I support this move. In fact, the legislation provides for a $1,000 fine if, once a device is banned, a citizen subsequently owns, supplies or possesses such a device.

While I support a ban on devices that interfere with radiocommunications traffic, I believe we need to go one step further and ban some other devices. I was a member of the Joint Select Committee on Telecommunications Interception which reported to the Parliament in November 1986. Recommendation 7 of that report stated:
With respect to the problem of illegal interception, the Committee concludes that:
a. the extent of illegal interception would be lessened if the availability of devices designed solely for telecommunications interception purposes were substantially reduced;
Later it recommended:

a. the manufacture, importation, advertising, sale and possession, installation and use of such devices be made illegal, and subject to penalties in accordance with those prescribed for physically effecting interceptions.

I am pleased to see the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) in the chamber as he was also a member of the Joint Select Committee on Telecommunications Interception. The Committee report very strongly recommended that the law be changed to prohibit people from owning, selling or possessing these devices which can be used to tap people's telephones. At the moment it is an offence to use the devices; it is an offence to attach an interception device to one's telephone. Rumour has it that one or two journalists in the Press gallery may use these types of devices to help them in their work as media representatives because their shorthand is not as good as it used to be. But it is an offence for anyone, whether a journalist or not, to attach a device to a telephone to record telephone conversations. Yet, while that is an offence, it is not an offence for Dick Smith Electronics, Woolworths or anyone else to sell devices that can be used to this effect. In fact, they are quite cheap. I am told that for less than $10 one can buy a device which enables one to start recording telephone conversations.

I believe that the Joint Select Committee's recommendation should be implemented. We should ban the importation of these devices. We should make it an offence for anyone to own the devices and we should also make it an offence to supply such devices. The fact that this legislation allows the Minister to ban devices which interfere with television reception is certainly commendable and should be supported. But I think that the right to have the privacy of one's telephone conversation respected, and to be assured of that total privacy, is more important than someone interfering with one's television reception through the use of a CB transmitter. I believe the Minister should consider extending this ban on devices which interfere or disrupt radiocommunications to cover any devices which can be used for the interception of telephone conversations.

While I am on the subject of communications matters, the report also recommended that the Government bring in legislation to prohibit the use of listening devices in the Australia Capital Territory. It is certainly a gap in the law of the land at the moment. I am pleased to see the honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly) in the chamber at the moment. There is certainly a hole in the statute law. In most States there is legislation which controls the use of listening devices, but there is no legislation which prohibits the use of listening devices in the Australian Capital Territory.

I was very disturbed last week when walking through one of the corridors in this building to see that one of the covers over the telephone connection boxes was unlocked and open. There was a folder listing all of the extension numbers and the titles of the people who were connected to those extension numbers. If someone had wished to place an intercept device on the telephones of those people, it would have been quite easy. Apparently, a technician had forgotten at the end of the day to restore the cover and place the padlocks on it. It is quite important that we maintain the maximum security possible on telecommunications devices in Parliament House. I assume it was an officer of Telecom Australia, as I understand it is responsible for maintaining the equipment in Parliament House. It is to be regretted that someone has behaved in this way and left open the possibility that some unauthorised person could have had access to some of the telephone lines used in this building.

I repeat that I support this legislation. What about every State railway department that runs at a loss of billions of dollars, part of which rural taxpayers in this country have to bear?

Australia is a big country. Those of us who live and work in it and travel across it will see that it is not only public enterprise which cross-subsidises. So does private enterprise, including the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd. All companies of any size cross-subsidise to help one business against the other, and at the end of the day the overall system is helped. That is the sort of system that we have built up in this country. Telecom has a mandate from this Parliament to give a phone to every Australian who wants one. It still has that mandate, and that is what is has to do. If it has to cross-subsidise to do it, so be it.

The same applies to the bodies listed in the Communications Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2). A number of communications bodies, et cetera have been mentioned. I am only sorry that this afternoon what I hope is one of the better ones, the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC), is not being used to broadcast this debate. Most of my constituents hear only the ABC, and it is a great pity that they cannot hear me giving them some support about their telephones and letting them know that they are the only people being time charged for their calls.

People living in the capital cities who are whingeing and whining about having to pay for time charged calls ought to think about those who are already paying. We are contributing towards the Telecom system over and above the people of the capital cities. That is the unjust system that is now in place. I call upon the Prime Minister, as I called upon him last week, to direct Telecom to withdraw the time charging method which has been in place in the Countrywide Calling system for the last two years. But what has he done about it? Nothing. He walks out of this place with his tail between his legs and does nothing about it.

This Bill, among other things, affects the Overseas Telecommunications Act 1946, the Postal Services Act 1975, the Radiocommunications Act 1983 and the Telecommunications Act 1975. It deals with hedging contracts. Telecommunications bodies are now able to hedge. I warn them that the Queensland Graingrowers Association, of which I am a member, went bankrupt by hedging. It lost $30m in hedging contracts and bankrupted itself. I assure this House that hedging is not quite the rose garden that people think it is. I warn these bodies, as I did previously in the legislation that went through this House concerning the Australian Wool Board, that one can lose money by hedging just as easily as one can lose money by playing the stock market.

That is absolute rubbish. It was a two- or three-day wonder. —That is not a point of order.
—I have tabled--
—That is not a point of order. I ask the honourable member for Maranoa to resume his seat. I call the honourable member for Chifley.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill, as I have said, is an omnibus Bill.
