Other changes will enable Australia Post and Telecom to issue securities not guaranteed by the Commonwealth. As has already been pointed out by the honourable member for Dobell, the honourable member for Goldstein made a very good point when he suggested that statutory authorities should be given inherent advantages and that advantages such as government guaranteed securities should remain and not be removed at the behest of private interests. Perhaps we ought to rethink that. Nevertheless, generally speaking, I am satisfied that this is a good proposal. The proposal for Australia Post which strengthens the law regarding sending explosives and other dangerous goods through the mail is a welcome introduction.

I say in conclusion-Mr Deputy Speaker, I appreciate that you have been very tolerant regarding my contribution to the debate-that it is ironic that the Opposition should have run such an intensive campaign against Telecom in the Adelaide by-election. I do not think that anyone challenges my position on untimed telephone calls, but I found it ironic that the Opposition presented an amendment with a series of points seeking to portray it as the great protector of Telecom, particularly when the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Kooyong, as recently as 29 January, has repeated consistently the Liberal Party's refrain that Telecom ought to be broken from its monopoly position. The Government is undertaking a thorough review of Telecom and, unless there has been a delay, the Minister will make a statement at the end of March.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robinson The Hon I.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Communications Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) is an omnibus Bill covering a vast number of matters affecting Telecom Australia, Australia Post and the Overseas Telecommunications Commission (OTC). The Bill virtually opens pandora's box on the whole gambit of the future of those three vital services to the Australian community. The debate has been very wide-ranging. It follows a very confused and lamentable political debate in the public arena over the last few months on the future of Telecom, Australia Post and the OTC. Its highlight was the support by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) for time charging. Then, as a consequence of the political pressures that he felt-the cold winds from the Adelaide by-election-he backed off and said, `No, it's not on. We've learnt our lesson'. Yet, within the first few days of the sitting of this House, we are confronted with legislation that re-opens the whole issue.

SPEECH.PARA: The issue has been re-opened because the fundamentals of the legislation relate to the financial structure of Telecom particularly, Australia Post to a lesser extent and OTC significantly. That financial structure is related directly to the debate that has gone on in the Australian Labor Party, the Caucus, and the very great concern expressed by the people of this country-the commercial sector and in particular ordinary householders-about Telecom's future. It is a future that is indeed a worry for all of us. On this side of the House there is a very great desire to ensure that we preserve one of the greatest services to the community that has ever been built up in any country. Ours is one of the most efficient and reliable telephone services in the world and it has been within the reach of the various sectors of the community to pay for it.

I refer, first of all, to the ordinary householder. Despite the fact that the charges are no longer cheap, one would have to regard them as reasonable in comparison with what they might well have been if the by-election had not turned up, a result that scared hell out of the Prime Minister-I will put it as strongly as that-so much so that, as I said earlier, he backed off because he had to do so. There was no way before then that he would listen in a rational manner to the concern of his backbenchers. I mention particularly the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price) and the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee). They and many others tried and failed to get recognition of the problem confronting that side of the House on this issue. Today in this place they are being very careful because they can see more trouble down the track regarding the future of Telecom, OTC and Australia Post. Any attempt to side track and to say that this side of the House is confused about future policies will not get them off the hook.

We must recognise that the May mini-Budget of 1986 was the first serious blow to cause the winds of change for Telecom. The introduction in that May mini-Budget of charges on the importation of equipment, which was a form of taxation of Telecom, for the first time, amounted to no less than $500m in the first year. We now learn that in the current financial year there is a short fall to the order of $300m. The truth is that under the present Government Telecom has become yet another avenue of heavy taxation. The figures given by the honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee) earlier in the debate should be heeded by every Australian, every telephone user and every member of this House. It is patently clear that Telecom is being turned into a tax collection agency. If that is to be part and parcel of Telecom's future, all the issues about privatisation, time charging and differentiation-that is, country versus city; cross-subsidisation-are insignificant. They are insignificant to the philosphy of turning Telecom into a taxing agency. Until there is a turnaround in that it does not matter what we do. We will end up with a botch, a mess, and we will see an extension of the kinds of things I will mention briefly in the short time at my disposal.

Since the last Budget Telecom has very quietly introduced new charges for the provision of new telephone services. One of the most blatant heavy charges being introduced-to enable it to be a greater tax gathering source for this Government-is a charge for the installation of telephone lines on a property once the first section of the line goes beyond 300 metres. There are many, many instances of that in every electorate outside metropolitan areas. As a result of the imposition of this new charge, charges can run to $700, $800, $900 or even $1,200 for a single telephone service to an ordinary home in Australia.

However, it is not only the principle of the charge that concerns my constituents and me and my colleagues such as the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Peter Fisher). We are concerned also that the charge is imposed on a notional basis. A positive estimate or costing is not done. The charge is calculated on the basis of someone sitting in an office and saying that the installation will require a dozer, a grader, and this that or the other, to put in this section of line; and therefore the cost will be estimated on that notional basis. Then the applicant is advised of the charge and he has to pay it before any action proceeds, before Telecom makes the slightest move to commence constructing the new line.

I instance a business enterprise in my electorate that in the last few weeks required a telephone service to be installed over the very short distance of a couple of kilometres. This company has invested a substantial amount of money, approximately $3.5m, and is very conscious of cost factors. As the company would provide local employment, it needed a telephone service. The company was told that under the new arrangements it would have to be charged for the construction of the line into the office in which it conducts its business. Quite consciously and objectively the company informed Telecom that it had cleared the line, the roadway was cleared, and the installation involved simply a matter of getting the line constructed and the equipment installed.

The company was given a quote of $40,000 to put in that short distance of telephone line. No clearing was involved, as that had been done. I think the installation took a day and a half. No matter how one considers it, whether on the basis of the number of men engaged, the plant used, or the equipment finally installed, one would require a vivid imagination to determine how the amount finally charged could be justified. I have asked Telecom Australia to give me some positive response as to how it arrived at that figure, and what was the basis of the charge imposed. I have not yet received even an acknowledgment of my representations, but I shall certainly follow them up.

I believe that the examples I have quoted, together with many other matters, provide a very sound reason for the people of Australia to become very alarmed about the administration of Telecom in terms of what it is now required to do by this Government. I believe that Telecom has been well managed, and continues to be well managed. However, it is now being shackled and being required to meet obligations that place it under financial strictures that are far too severe.

My colleague the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron) referred to some aspects of the cost of telephones outside metropolitan areas. We certainly know that cross-subsidisation has been an essential element of the development of telephone networks in this country. However, would any Australian want to see the disintegration of this great service to this country? I am sure he would not. If one thinks back, it is only a short time ago that if one made a call from the eastern States to Perth, or vice versa, one would have to wait to be connected, would have a problem with heavy traffic and getting through, and the quality of the connection often was not satisfactory.

As part of an overall network expansion, all of our capital cities were linked so that there was an immediate service and an immediate connection with, really, no limits. The traffic is now carried adequately. That involved the construction of a cable system and the advent of new technology and the use of systems that were installed during the past decade or so throughout country areas of Australia to serve not only the metropolitan areas but also every other Australian community. Improved services were provided to the great north-west of this country, to the far-flung sectors of Queensland and western New South Wales. Through all the areas on the fringe of heavy population centres, our major cities, whether in Victoria, New South Wales, Queensland, or any of the other States and Territories, a network has been built up without providing a burden in any way, shape or form on the taxpayers of this country.

Now, because there is a very efficient system, the Government has decided that it has to obtain revenue from it, to throw into the general pool of taxation, into the extravagant spending spree that this Government undertook. The consequence has been to seek ways and means of a form of privatisation. The debate that has taken place in Caucus about telephone time charging will pale into insignificance when Caucus faces up to the reality of what privatisation really entails under the present Government's policies.

To suggest that the Opposition does not know where it is at with regard to this policy is sheer rubbish. Perhaps there have been statements by a senator or two; perhaps there have been odd comments by one or two who are not directly experienced in this matter. However, I can assure the House that on the Opposition side of this House, and certainly within the National Party, there are those who will not let down Australia with regard to the future of Telecom, Australia Post, or OTC. For that reason the amendment moved by the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) deserves the attention of honourable members on both sides of the House. It raises pertinent points about where we are going on the whole policy issue of the future of Telecom, Australia Post, and OTC.

Despite what has been said by the Minister who introduced this legislation and by those honourable members who have spoken in support of it on behalf of the Government, both in another place and in this chamber, the future of those three organisations is still shrouded in mystery. That shroud will be removed only if people such as the honourable member for Chifley-who asserted that there was some lack of understanding on this side of the House, and that protection of the service in the future will come from that side of the House-make clear what is the Government's real policy on privatisation not only of Telecom but also of a number of other instrumentalities in this country.

If the truth be known, it seems without doubt that the real purpose, the hidden agenda, is to raise more revenue for the Government. We have seen that, of course, as one consequence of the last Budget. We are yet to see, in a few weeks time, the contents of the promised May mini-Budget. Perhaps then we will learn the real truth. The sell-off of many of the assets referred to in the Budget Speech, to make it possible for the Budget to be balanced, has run into pretty rough water. A few difficulties for the Treasurer (Mr Keating) are beginning to emerge, about which not much has been said. There is no doubt that with regard to this matter the debate has ranged merely over the surface of the real issues relating to privatisation. We need to get our feet on the ground and to ensure that the consequences of what is being engineered are not detrimental to commercial interests and to the householders of this nation. On this side of the House it will be our task to make assessments and judgments. We will do that and we will not need any reminding about our attitude to policy. There will not be any question of shifting around. We will have a positive approach.

I ask the Government to come clean about its intentions. This is its opportunity to do so. It has legislation before the Parliament, so this is the time to come out and tell us its proposition on these few matters that are being opened up. In particular, we should heed the warning of the honourable member for Maranoa about the dangers in hedging as far as borrowing is concerned. There are real issues there that should not be allowed to go through without adequate explanation because the financial status of Australia in the borrowing field today is of great concern to all of us. We know that our borrowing commitment has grown-quite apart from what the Budget tells us-because the figures speak for themselves. We have the greatest debt ever and the cost of servicing it, likewise, has gone out of all proportion to what the taxpayers of this country should be expected to carry.

Much of that comes down to the issue of priorities in spending. If the milking cow approach, which is used to try to solve some of these unwise government policies, hits Telecom, OTC and Australia Post, and then directly the users of those services, it is just not good enough. I support the amendments that have been proposed and I deplore the Government's lack or real sincerity in relation to the issues raised in this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I begin my remarks by taking up a couple of issues that were raised by the honourable member for Page (Mr Ian Robinson). One concerns the question of time charging and cost recovery. We made a very clear statement, which came out of Caucus last week, that this Government would not proceed with the time charging of local calls. All honourable members who are following this debate should be aware that it is very clear that the time charging of local calls will not be proceeded with.

SPEECH.PARA: Those who are looking at the issue in the context of the New South Wales election should ask members of the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia to enunciate their policy. Is their policy one of cost recovery? If it is one of cost recovery, and an attempt to move towards the `user pays' principle, which the Liberal Party has endorsed, then those people can well expect pressure for time charging from Liberal and National Party members. Certainly, if electors are trying to make up their minds about the New South Wales election, they should be reminded that the decision of the Federal parliamentary Labor Party is to oppose time charging of local calls and that that decision is clearly supported by the Unsworth Government in New South Wales. They should also be reminded that the Unsworth Government is concerned about the welfare of ordinary individuals and that the Federal parliamentary Labor Party is aware of the needs of ordinary people in New South Wales, and in Sydney in particular. There are many excellent members in this House representing those seats, two of whom spoke before me in the debate. We heard the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee) and the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price). Even earlier, the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) spoke. All those members represent their electorates with considerable concern for their constituents and they are anxious to point out to them that they oppose time charging of local calls.

At this stage, the question still unresolved is the one concerning the user pays principle, which has been endorsed by the Liberal Party and which carries with it the recognition of time charging of local calls. That is a considerable dilemma that faces the electors of New South Wales. To resolve that dilemma, I point out that it has been made clear by the Federal parliamentary Labor Party that we oppose time charging local calls. I wish to develop this point further. It has been recognised by speakers on both sides that time charging poses problems. One of the difficulties was that, in effect, Telecom Australia was saying, without understanding the nature of the community, that suddenly its telephone system was being clogged up by facsimile machines and computers. Yet it was clear to ordinary telephone subscribers that they had never asked for that movement in technology. In fact, ordinary telephone subscribers in the electorate simply want cheap, reliable telephones. Most telephone subscribers have not asked for the sophisticated technology that has been introduced more recently. Therefore, it is fair to say that they ought not have their charging basis changed because Telecom has found that its network is clogged up by these other activities.

I take up the point raised by the honourable member for Dobell. I am yet to be convinced, by Telecom or by anyone else for that matter, that a facsimile machine ties up a telephone line for an extended period. It is not true. Facsimile machines, if anything, tend to minimise the impact upon the telephone system because a lot of voice communication is now sent in the form of facsimile documents. Certainly, between my office in Perth and the office in Canberra, we use the facsimile machine in place of telephone calls. It minimises the amount of time that a telephone line is tied up. I take very strong issue with Telecom when it makes such allegations.

Also, I do not think that Telecom understands what is meant by disadvantaged people in this community because its definition of `disadvantaged' is too narrow. It tends to see only pensioners as being disadvantaged. I put to Telecom and to the community in general, that there are many people on very modest superannuation payouts, for example, some of them in the Federal Public Service and others in the private sector, who in real terms are no better off than a pensioner who has all the fringe benefits. If those people were faced with time charging of local calls, they would be considerably disadvantaged. But nowhere in the literature that was put out by Telecom is there any mention of superannuants. Yet, as I say, many of those who are on modest superannuation are very often as economically disadvantaged as those on a full pension.

There is also no attention paid, for example, to the benefit a telephone provides for a woman at home with three small children. It is clear that, in those circumstances, where a woman at home has children in their very early years the chance of that woman getting out and about in the community is minimised because of the demands of the children. Very often, the telephone provides the only form of communication for her. I am not being sexist and saying that there are no men at home who look after their children, but it is true that the majority of child care in this country is still carried on by women at home. In those circumstances, how does one deal with the social disadvantage if that woman has to pay for the length of time she is on the telephone? She is not perhaps economically disadvantaged, but if she were discouraged from using the telephone she would clearly become socially disadvantaged. That is unacceptable to me and my colleagues on this side of the House, such as the honourable member for Chifley. Telecom should understand something of the social processes in this community. Many women with children in their early years find that the telephone is the only source of communication, particularly if they live in outer suburbs and do not drive or have access to a vehicle. They then find that the telephone is very important to communicate with their friends. To impose time charging upon them would impose a severe social disadvantage.

Let me elaborate further. Telecom showed its inability to understand the nature of the community when it spoke of giving a discounted rate in the evening for people to make telephone calls. It stated that many of the older people in the community would find that they would be helped by that discount. In fact, if Telecom understood anything at all about elderly people, it would realise that this was not so. If I ring my mother at 8.30 p.m. or 8.45 p.m., she thinks that my children are sick. Many elderly people who take phone calls at night or in the early morning think there is sickness in the family. Therefore, why would they use the discounted phone system? They would not use it. Telecom shows a complete lack of understanding of its consumers. Old people do not use telephones at night. It is a waste of time offering them discounts because, very simply, they do not make calls at night except in emergencies. Therefore, it is no good coming up with a brochure which says, `We will give you a cheaper rate at night' because elderly people will not use that service at night. For those three reasons, let alone the many others, the time charging system is not on. I am pleased that my colleagues from New South Wales have very strongly supported that position. I say to voters in New South Wales: Think carefully, because on this issue we are clear. The Federal parliamentary Labor Party and the Government as a whole are opposed to time charging for local calls. That cannot be said of the Liberal Party of Australia or the National Party of Australia. If one is looking at this situation from the perspective of the New South Wales State election it is clear that the interests of telephone subscribers in New South Wales will be protected by the Australian Labor Party and the Unsworth Labor Government, not by the choices being offered by the Liberal and National parties or by the Greiner Opposition.

The next point I want to deal with in this debate relates to my concern about the signal distribution for AM radio stations in Perth. The second reading speech on the Communications Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) referred to the radio frequency spectrum being a limited resource. There is a very severe technical and commercial problem facing AM radio stations in Perth. I refer specifically to radio stations 6PM, 6IX, 6KY and 6PR which all operate with two-kilowatt transmitters. The nature of the soil condition in metropolitan Perth, which has a sandy soil base with very little rock substratum is vastly different from that in Sydney, for example, where there is a substratum of sandstone and granite; Melbourne, where there is basalt and granite; or Brisbane, which also has a rock base. Those conditions in Perth are rather unusual. As a result, it is very difficult to distribute an AM radio signal. In fact, what happens is that it simply fades out; it does not bounce over the surface of the earth.

There is a very rapidly expanding population in Perth. Like every other city in Australia, people are moving into the outer suburbs. In Perth they are moving into the northern outer suburbs, into the electorates of my colleagues the honourable member for Cowan (Ms Jakobsen) and the honourable member for Moore (Mr Blanchard). It is also true to say that a lot of those people can no longer clearly receive AM radio signals from stations 6PM, 6IX, 6KY and 6PR. These stations have a problem commercially as well. How do they reach an audience if their signals cannot be received by that audience? Vis-a-vis radio stations such as 96FM, which has no problem with air radio distribution, the AM stations are faced with an immense problem. This has been dealt with by debate and discussion for a number of years. So far there has not been a satisfactory resolution.

There are three possible solutions. One solution is to upgrade the power of the transmitters. For example, 6WF or Australian Broadcasting Corporation Radio 1 in Perth has a 50-kilowatt transmitter. There are very few distribution problems and, in fact, one can pick up its signal right across metropolitan Perth and in nearby country areas. Radio station 6WA Wagin also has a 50-kilowatt transmitter and has no difficulty in distributing its signal. However, the AM radio stations in Perth do have a distribution problem because they are on a much lower power.

The first option is to upgrade the power of the transmitter. However, unless it is upgraded from two kilowatts to something like 20 kilowatts there would still be difficulty in distributing the signal. The second option is to install relays so that the AM radio signal that is distributed initially is picked up by a relay and transmitted on. That is a possibility. However, it involves a technical difficulty because, once again, the AM spectrum is being clogged up. It is not easy for radio station broadcasts and other services to be carried on the AM band if relays are installed.

The third and most effective solution to the problem is, in fact, to allow the AM radio stations to convert to the FM band. There would then be no difficulties in signal distribution because the FM band has a much easier technical distribution basis. That is not without commercial consequences because in metropolitan Australia those FM radio stations are very profitable. Those stations took the risk and became FM stations. The FM radio stations in cities around Australia tend to be at the top of the ratings and are doing very well commercially. It is also true to say that a lot of the AM radio stations are being left behind in terms of both the quality of their signal and its distribution. That is most severe in Perth.

I am acknowledging in my comments that there is a technical solution to the problem which is to allow all the AM radio stations to convert to FM. Obviously, there is also a commercial consequence in Perth, that is that 96FM will suddenly find itself with four commercial competitors. This Government recognises that a decision of that magnitude is not easy. In fact, I have put the proposition that we ought to consider Perth to be a special case. We should allow the AM radio stations in Perth to overcome the distribution problem. Clearly, I think we can make a case for allowing Western Australia and Perth in particular to do that immediately because stations there are suffering enormous problems. The boundary of my electorate is North Beach Road which is not very far from the centre of Perth-in old terms it is probably about seven miles. If one drives a bit further north one can barely receive the four AM radio stations. People will understand the consequences of that. Once one travels 10 kilometres beyond the transmitter the signal almost disappears whereas 96FM can be received very strongly further north. I recognise that radio station 96FM took the risk, and it has succeeded. But the AM radio stations are still clearly disadvantaged. I believe that the Government should address this problem as a priority. If it does not agree to general conversion of radio stations to FM at least it should agree to the particular conversion of radio stations in Perth. I believe it is important.

I now move to the third issue I wish to raise which concerns the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. Recently, there have been a number of complaints about the advertising of Havana cigars on radio and television in Perth. The Broadcasting Tribunal has been very legalistic about this and said, `We will not ban the advertising of cigars because we believe that it is outside the scope of section 100 (5a) of the relevant legislation'. However, it is my view that the Tribunal is ducking the issue. It has been determined by health Ministers and admitted by the tobacco industry that smoking is harmful to health. There has been an agreement concerning the limitation of cigarette advertising on television and radio. However, there has not been a willingness by the Tribunal to face up to the reality that cigars are just as harmful and have just the same impact on people's health. The only technical difference is that cigars are made from uncut tobacco, whereas cigarettes are made from cut tobacco. However, the Tribunal has the nerve to say that it has an opinion from the Attorney-General's Department which says that cigars are outside the scope of the Act. Clearly, cigars are capable of injuring people but, the Tribunal is saying that they are outside the scope of the Act. That is not satisfactory. It is not satisfactory from my point of view and it is certainly not satisfactory from the point of view of many constituents.

I acknowledge the work of a gentleman called Adrian Chambers in the community newspapers in Perth who has been drawing this matter to the attention of a large number of people in the community. For people who hear television or radio advertising for cigars and who, as a consequence consume that product, there is no difference whatsoever in terms of their health between cigars and cigarettes. In fact, both cigarettes and cigars have been determined as being harmful to health. The tobacco industry acknowledges that both are harmful to health. Therefore, why is the Tribunal not courageous enough to say that cigars come within section 100 (5a) of the Act?

I do not believe that it is good enough for the Tribunal to hide behind an opinion previously given by the Attorney-General's Department based on an interpretation of the Act that reference to cigars is outside the scope of section 100 (5a) since that provision deals only with advertisements for cigarettes or cigarette tobacco. Cigars are made from cigarette tobacco, except that the tobacco is not cut. What a nonsense it is in terms of the way in which the Tribunal is dealing with its social responsibility.

I take up the issue of social responsibility. We have allowed the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to deregulate the number of advertisements per hour that television stations are allowed to transmit. What is happening already is that television stations are abusing that deregulation. People have complained to me. I believe that what we as backbenchers might have to begin to do is to monitor what television stations are doing in this respect. Clearly, they are bunching up lots of advertisements. I am not without some sympathy for the television stations but if they run 23 minutes of commercials per hour in the middle of a particularly good program one can challenge whether those television stations are fulfilling their social responsibility. It is not satisfactory for them to say that they will operate in a deregulated environment and block out an hour with a substantial number of ads. I believe that the Government might well need to ask the Tribunal to produce some figures very soon-I understand that the Tribunal is commencing monitoring-so that people on both sides of the House can see whether their communities are being served by the new deregulated scenario of television advertising.

I return to my initial point that I do not believe it is good enough for the industry to be allowed to get away with advertising cigars on radio and television because the Tribunal takes what I regard as a legalistic definition of section 100 (5a) instead of taking a responsible view which says, `We recognise that cigars are made from cigarette tobacco'. What nonsense it is to pretend that they are not. Therefore, the health consequences are the same and the Tribunal should say, `You cannot advertise. We will apply the same sanctions or strictures as we currently do to the advertising of cigarettes, because they represent one of the major health problems facing the community'. The Tribunal ought to recognise its responsibilities. If it does not, we in this chamber ought to remind it and the industry of their responsibilities.

We have talked about interfering with signals. There is a big problem for electors in the Perth suburb of Scarborough in my electorate. People will know that the Observation City Resort Hotel, a very large building built by Bond Corporation Pty Ltd, has deprived hundreds of residents of Scarborough of a television signal. It is one thing to talk about interference from other devices, but what happened was that the local government authority, the City of Stirling, was unable in its planning to take account of the fact that a large building may interfere with people's amenity. The State Government planning authority was unable to take account of that because its definition of planning was too narrow. It was concerned only with the engineering constraints, not the social constraints.

This Government ought to be saying that television reception is an amenity for the general community and we ought to ensure that that amenity is provided. If developers can go ahead and build high rise buildings which interfere with people's reception of a basic amenity like television, the planning processes have to be challenged. We ought to be prepared to insert in legislation before this chamber a clause which enables us, if necessary, to talk to the planning authorities at the State and local level and direct them accordingly to protect the television reception of our constituents. I am pleased to commend the legislation to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOLDING
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —In summing up the contributions made by honourable members to this debate I remind the House that the Communications Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 is essentially an omnibus miscellaneous provisions Bill designed to introduce some minor amendments in the area of communications. It is clear from the nature of the debate that the provisions are generally quite unexceptional and I think it is true to say that no honourable member expressed any difficulties with the Bill as a Bill. However, as one would expect, honourable members used the breadth of the Bill to range over a number of issues relevant to communications in Australia. A number of statements will have to be answered at some little length because, if they are allowed to remain uncorrected, they will cause not merely confusion and misunderstanding but also concern in many parts of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The first of those statements was made by the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) when he said that the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron) had claimed-the honourable member for Maranoa subsequently claimed this in his speech-that time charge arrangements apply in rural Australia for most but not all calls. He endeavoured to challenge the very clear commitment given by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Government-and indeed subsequently endorsed in the strongest of terms by the parliamentary Labor Party in its Caucus meeting-that the Government will not go down the track of timed local calls. He has confused that situation with a situation which was created some time ago by Telecom Australia.

Let me place on the record, so that there can be no misunderstanding, that local calls in western Queensland are charged at a flat rate, as they are everywhere else in Australia. Local calls are calls made within a 32-kilometre radius of an exchange in rural areas. The community call rate, which is currently 20c for three minutes or about 7c a minute, applies in extended charging zones beyond local call areas. Many of those zones exceed 10,000 square kilometres and some exceed 100,000 square kilometres. The community call rate also applies as part of Telecom's Access 80 scheme to country areas where local call access was not formerly available to a serviced town. In the case of an electorate like Maranoa, which is very large, or an electorate like Kalgoorlie, which takes up a huge geographic area, what Telecom did was to ensure that people living in those rural situations were able to get access to their local exchange; and for that they paid the community call rate as it applies universally.

Clearly, one cannot expect to make a call over a large geographic area at the local call rate. The electorate of Maranoa seems to go virtually from one side of Queensland to the other. The normal subscriber trunk dialling (STD) charges apply there. That is the reality. To try to interpret that as somehow representing a grave injustice to people living within that electorate, or to imply that there is some kind of hidden agenda which belies the commitment given by the Government and the Prime Minister on time charged calls, is either to be entirely ignorant of the system that has been put in to the benefit of rural users, or to be politically mischievous. I will leave it to the House to determine which of those aspects applies to the honourable member for Richmond and to the honourable member for Maranoa.

I come back to the point that, if one lives as I do in the metropolitan area of Melbourne and wants to make a call to Mildura, Ballarat or Bendigo, that is an STD call. Someone living in one part of Maranoa ringing across the extremities of the electorate would be in exactly the same position as a Melbourne resident ringing a country STD area. Telecom introduced the system so as not to disadvantage people living in isolated rural communities who needed to be able to get the same benefits as the average user. Although they may be living some distance from their local exchange, they get the benefit of the community telephone call charge. That is something that needs to be understood. It is simply not true to suggest, as the honourable member for Maranoa suggested, that there is some hidden agenda by which this Government is proposing to abolish the cross-subsidy which provides an equality of usage and availability to people living in remote areas. It does not aid the debate that needs to take place about how effectively our communications system can and should operate to perpetuate that sort of argument.

No-one in the Government and no-one in Telecom is talking about an abandonment of cross-subsidy. What is true is that, if one were to take a simplistic assertion in favour of privatisation and use it in the way in which it is used by members of the Opposition, as a panacea to solve all our problems, and if Telecom were given to a private company whose function it was to make a profit, one of the very effective ways of making very handsome profits would be to abandon the whole concept of cross-subsidisation. The first duty of a director in a private company is to ensure that the profits are maximised for the benefit of shareholders. That is one of the distinctions between Telecom and a private company. Telecom has a public duty and that public duty has manifested itself in its general approach to the development of effective telecommunications services throughout Australia.

The other proposal which I want to deal with is the suggestion, which came also from the honourable member for Maranoa; and from the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown), that Australia Post proposes to adopt the policy of charging for the delivery of post on the basis of distance. That is a nonsense proposition. It was first asserted by the honourable member for Menzies on the basis of a report he had received.

TALK.START.PARA: —The union agreed. It had been looked at.

—I was about to inform the honourable gentleman that the government which sought advice on this proposal was the Fraser Government and the Minister at the time who received that report, which was provided, presumably, at the request of his Government, was the honourable member for Menzies. Let us not have any doubt at all about the origins of this proposition. On the basis of that, an action of a previous government, the honourable member for Menzies floated the proposition that this was part of the current or hidden agenda of Australia Post. That was specifically and publicly denied. I say, as the Minister who was involved in that area, that there was no truth in the assertion that that proposition is anywhere on the agenda, either of those who run Australia Post or of this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: If the honourable member for Menzies wants to have his flights of fancy, he is entitled to do that. He may, if he wants, mislead his own colleagues and distort the situation, in clear conflict with the very clear denials that have been made in this matter by the Government and by the relevant officers who have responsibility in this matter. They have made it perfectly clear that, so long as the monopoly that is held by Australia Post continues, this is not in any way on the political agenda. The honourable member for Menzies knows that. It was his Government that sought the report. It was part of the ongoing philosophy of those opposite which flows from their preparedness to sell off anything they can in the absence of an economic policy. I repudiate the proposition on behalf of the Government.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the whole the Opposition is quite happy with the Commonwealth Teaching Service Amendment Bill 1987 as it attempts to streamline the Teaching Service and, therefore, make it more efficient. It is mainly an administrative Bill that amends the Commonwealth Teaching Service Act 1972 so that the areas of promotions, transfers, appeals, forfeiture of office and attachment of salary will be subject to similar conditions as those that apply under the Public Service Act. The Bill also makes provision for the transfer of staff from the Service to certain Commonwealth authorities if required. This provision has been made to make way for the expected transfer of staff from the Canberra technical and further education colleges, the Canberra School of Art and the Canberra School of Music to the proposed Australian Capital Territory Institute of TAFE and the proposed Canberra Institute of the Arts once it has been established. This provision also enables officers to be transferred to other statutory authorities in the future if it is deemed necessary.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill also provides for technical changes to remove inconsistencies from the Act. The proposed new section 28 deals with the selection on merit of officers for promotion or transfer. The new procedure will be that the Service will select from those officers the officer who is, in the opinion of the relevant authority, the most efficient. The Service will take into account the abilities, qualifications, experience, standard of work performance, and personal qualities of each officer to the extent that the relevant authority considers that those matters are relevant to the performance of duties of the position. Proposed new section 28 (3) states:

For the purposes of subsection (2), an officer who is a returned soldier or who is or has been absent on specified defence service shall be treated as having the abilities, qualifications, experience, standard of work performance, personal qualities, potential for future career development in the Service, or ability to perform the duties of the positions concerned that, in the opinion of the relevant authority, the officer would have had but for the absence of the officer on active service or on specified defence service.

The Opposition has the firm opinion that promotion should be on merit, not just on seniority. That is what this Bill takes into account. There are expected to be no additional costs involved and, in fact, some minor savings may occur through the reduction in the number of appeals required to be determined by the promotions appeal boards.

However, we are not happy about clause 7 of the Bill, which may leave applicants open to discrimination and which we propose to amend. Clause 7 deals with joint selection committees. At present, a joint selection committee may refuse to consider an application on the basis that the applicant is not a member of a staff organisation. We wish to make provision to prevent such discrimination and also to prevent a joint selection committee or a member of a joint selection committee, when assessing the claims of the applicants, taking into consideration whether an applicant is a member of a relevant staff organisation.

The Opposition does not consider it relevant or necessary that the applicant be a member of a union and we want to ensure that those applicants are protected from any such discrimination, otherwise this Bill will institutionalise compulsory unionism. Although the Government has insisted that this is not the case, there are so many ways in which compulsory unionism exists in fact although not in legislation. This is the one area of the legislation that we oppose and we will be moving amendments to that aspect of the Bill at the committee stage. That is the main problem we have with the Bill. Other than that, the Opposition is satisfied that the Bill will bring out improvements in the administration of the Teaching Service and allow for greater efficiency in the Service.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snowdon Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —As an ex-member of the Commonwealth Teaching Service and as a former employee of the Northern Territory Teaching Service, I support the Commonwealth Teaching Service Bill 1987 and I oppose the Opposition's proposed amendments. The Commonwealth Teaching Service Act 1972 originally provided the legislative framework for the employment of teachers in Commonwealth schools and certain other schools. The Australian Capital Territory (ACT) technical and further education sector provided teachers for preschools, primary schools, secondary schools, colleges and TAFE colleges. It originally provided teachers for the Northern Territory, but with the transfer of powers to the Northern Territory Government in 1978 and the setting up of the Northern Territory Teaching Service in 1981 this was no longer necessary. The Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority, as the relevant authority under the Act, maintains responsibility for providing teachers to Christmas Island, which is also in my electorate.

SPEECH.PARA: On 12 December 1985 the Governor-General approved administrative arrangements which allocated responsibility for the administration of the Act between the Minister for Education and the Minister for Territories. On 12 December 1985 the Minister for Territories assumed responsibility for preschool, primary and secondary education in the Australian Capital Territory. The Minister for Education continues to maintain responsibility for all matters other than those specified for the Minister for Territories, and this includes retention of responsibility for the Office of Australian Capital Territory Further Education. The Public Service Board continues to determine terms and conditions of employment.

In the case of Australian Capital Territory government schools, the Chief Education Officer of the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority is the relevant authority under the Act responsible for making teachers available. Both Ministers also have the power to direct relevant authorities under certain circumstances to provide teachers to teach in schools conducted by other countries or in cases where a State or State authority makes a teacher available to a Commonwealth school.

Funds for the administration of the Act are not appropriated separately, but are provided mainly from the appropriations of the Commonwealth Department of Education and the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority. The current amendments to the Act, as the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) pointed out, are aimed at streamlining the administration of the Act and were originally foreshadowed in the 1986 annual report of the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority, which in part said:

Amendments to certain sections of the Act are in preparation to bring conditions of officers of the Service more into line with those of officers in the Australian Public Service, particularly on matters covered in the public service streamlining legislation. Some of the proposed changes are the removal of seniority as a factor for consideration in promotions, amendment of the definition of efficiency, and provision for the formation of joint selection committees and for the limitation of appeal rights in the promotion process.

The Bill puts those foreshadowed proposals in place, with the principal amendment bringing the Commonwealth Teaching Service Act into line with the Public Service Act 1922 as amended by the Public Service Legislation (Streamlining) Act 1986. This was pointed out in the second reading speech.

In the area of promotions, transfers, appeals and forfeiture of office and attachment of salary, provision is also made for the transfer of staff from the Commonwealth Teaching Service to certain other Commonwealth authorities. I will not repeat what the then Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories said in his second reading speech about the matter of promotions and appeals mechanisms; suffice it to say that they are seen by all parties as an improvement on the present system.

Two significant points arise from this legislation. As far as the detail of the Bill is concerned, the Australian Capital Territory Teachers Federation was consulted about the form of the amendments and through this process agreement was reached. In contrast to the archaic approach to industrial relations that typifies the attitude of the Opposition, this Government has shown its preparedness to involve its employees in a meaningful and positive way in the development of its policies. The amendments also demonstrate a preparedness of the Australian Capital Territory Teachers Federation to look at existing practices and improve them in a way which will release resources tied up in complicated administrative procedures and allow those resources to apply to education. The only time the Opposition parties tried to streamline the Commonwealth Teaching Service Act was when it applied the Commonwealth Employees (Employment Provisions) Act to teachers in 1982. At that time they were not being given a decent hearing on salaries. The Fraser Government overreacted to some industrial action and sacked most of the teachers under this draconian legislation. This only served to unite the teaching service, and the then Government was forced to back off quicker than a lion tamer without a whip.

The public education system in the ACT has a lot to be proud of. In speaking to this Bill, I would like to place on record my total support for the public education system not only here in the ACT but elsewhere in Australia. The ACT education system has recorded some very impressive results. It has the highest retention rates in Australia with 90 per cent of it, public school students completing year 12. That rate is higher than any other system, public or private, in Australia. It is twice the national average. In addition, 86 per cent of government secondary college students seeking admission to universities and colleges of advanced education are accepted. Most normal aged graduates who win Australian National University medals are from ACT secondary colleges.

The high school and college courses are structured to encourage continuation at school until year 12. There are programs for students with special needs. New courses, programs and policies are being introduced as the need arises in areas such as computing, Asian languages, employment courses at secondary colleges, encouragement for girls to study maths and science, early literacy and special primary reading programs, enrichment programs for gifted students, equal opportunity in education programs, gender equity, new discipline processes and work experience. In addition to that, the needs of the community are met in terms of the structure of school boards where the chairperson is usually a parent and the board develops a school's philosophy and policies and approves the education programs.

In the ACT the public sector gets value for money. The voluntary contribution each year in public schools is around $25 a head at primary schools, $50 at high schools and $100 at colleges. The alternative would cost thousands of dollars. With what is saved from using public education one could buy one's child a computer, build up a large reference or fiction library, take one's child to the theatre, buy one's child a musical instrument, take the child on educational trips in Australian or abroad or help support him or her later at college or university.
The current head of the ACT Schools Authority, Eric Willmot, in an article on 2 February 1988 in the Canberra Times, said:
Australian public school systems have been able to create virtually universal literacy in a continent of deterring geographical difficulties.
I would like to emphasise the importance of that statement for people not only in the ACT but elsewhere in Australia who send their children to public sector schools. He went on to say:
Whereas secondary education once served almost solely those who were aiming for higher education, schools now prepare students for all kinds of career paths.
The results and statistics show that the ACT public school system is doing this more successfully than any other kinds of schools in Australia.
Parents in the ACT are fortunate in having the public school system they possess, not in terms of the level of resources provided, but in the quality of the system.

The quality of the system depends on the quality of the teachers. In my view the Commonwealth Teaching Service is and has been extremely well served by the present teachers and those who formerly were employed.

By contrast, the sister service of the Commonwealth Teaching Service that grew out of that body-the Northern Territory Teaching Service, does not have such a record. It is not because the Northern Territory teachers are any less dedicated or any less able. But, unfortunately, there is a crisis of confidence in the way in which the Northern Territory Minister for Education and the Northern Territory Government generally are administering their responsibilities in relation to education. The education service in the Northern Territory is renowned for the lack of consultation about aspects of education with the school community generally and with teachers in particular. The Northern Territory Minister responsible for education finds that he can better use his time by attacking teachers, suggesting that they should spend more time in the classroom addressing their school duties and less on political interests because they have the temerity to argue about the education programs that the Northern Territory Teaching Service is offering.

The Minister for Education in the Northern Territory Government could take a leaf out of the document of the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) entitled Democratic Decision-making in the Work Force, which points out quite clearly that people must be involved in things which give them the opportunity to influence the outcome, and this means consultation with people in the workplace. In this instance, it means proper and adequate consultation with teachers in the Teaching Service who have the job of delivering the education system to our students. This is very important at a time when needs are changing, when demands on the Teaching Service are increasing and where teachers are expected to produce a higher return. I have great pleasure in supporting this Bill. I emphasise once again that it is important to recognise the role of ACT Teachers and public sector teachers generally in the way they carry out their duties. I applaud the legislation before the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although the Opposition intends to move amendments at the committee stage, which the shadow Minister has outlined, the Opposition in general supports the Commonwealth Teaching Service Amendment Bill 1987. I would like to make a couple of comments on the contribution made by the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon). Other than the rather raw and unnecessary attacks that he delivered against the Opposition parties and apart from the attack he made on the Northern Territory Minister for Education, there is probably a lot in what he said that members on this side of the House would agree with. The theme or centrepiece of the Bill is to ensure that efficiency is the sole determinant in promotions. The definition of efficiency has itself been broadened to allow a relevant authority to consider an applicant's potential for future career development and his or her ability to perform the duties of other positions at the same level. Those words are taken from the second reading speech of the then Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories.

SPEECH.PARA: If we are to judge an applicant's potential for future career development and his or her ability to perform the duties of other positions at the same level, I believe that it is also appropriate that we look at the plight of those who wish to become teachers.

Madam Speaker, the honourable member for the Northern Territory was allowed to make a fairly wide-ranging speech. I do not wish to be provocative in any way, which I will not be. Let us look at the parameters that confront somebody who wants to become a teacher. Madam Speaker, if you view my comments in that context I think you will feel a lot more easy. I want to talk about an Austudy anomaly. A person who wants to qualify for an independent Austudy benefit has to have worked for three out of the last four years, or 156 out of 280 weeks. The definition of `work' includes real work, sick leave, recreation leave, being on the unemployment benefit or the sole-parent benefit or Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) registration. One also qualifies if one has performed real work, been unemployed or been registered with the CES for the past three years. These requirements are designed for somebody who wants to get into the Commonwealth Teaching Service.

Let us consider the following case: Jack has a full-time job in 1984. He is on the dole in 1985 and 1986 and for the first six months of 1987 when he then gets a job. This means that in 1984 he had 52 weeks of real work; in 1985, 52 weeks on the unemployment benefit; in 1986, 52 weeks on the benefit; in 1987, 26 weeks on the benefit and 26 weeks in real work. That means 78 weeks of real work and 130 weeks on the benefit out of a total of 208 weeks. Jack is now eligible to get Austudy as a full time student, obtain independent status and get benefits for, say, three years. Between 1984 and 1990 Jack will have worked for only 78 weeks in seven years. He will have spent three years at university or at teachers college on Austudy, 1 1/2 years doing real work and 2 1/2 years on the unemployment benefit.

Let us take the case of Jill. Jill also wants to become a Commonwealth teacher. She worked full time throughout 1985, 1986 and most of 1987. For the last four weeks of 1987 she was out of work but did not receive an unemployment benefit and was not registered at the CES. Let us look at Jill's chances of becoming a teacher, particularly in view of the lines in the former Minister's second reading speech about future career development in accordance with ability, et cetera. What has Jill done? In 1985, she had 52 weeks of real work; in 1986, 52 weeks of real work; and, in 1987, 48 weeks of real work and four weeks when she was not on the dole on a benefit registered as unemployed, et cetera. She may well have thought that she was just having an unpaid holiday. So what it amounted to was 152 weeks of real work and four weeks not on any benefit.

Jack spent 130 weeks on the dole, which is considered as work. Only one month did Jill not work and never in three years did she claim any form of benefit. In fact, she never once drew upon Commonwealth support in the whole time. She paid taxes which actually supported Jack. Jack can now go to the Commonwealth teachers training college to become a Commonwealth teacher, in accordance with the Bill, but Jill cannot go because she is four weeks short of qualifying for independent status Austudy benefit. I use the debate on this legislation to raise what I regard as a very unfair anomaly. If we are about higher education for people in future, it is absolutely ridiculous that people who have contributed to the community so meaningfully can be excluded in that way.

The honourable member for the Northern Territory spoke about the excellence of the Australian Capital Territory is of a very high standard. I have often said to people that although I would not live in this place, if I had kids-which I do-I would not mind sending them to school in the Australian Capital Territory. One cannot help thinking that it has its advantages. It certainly has its advantages. A few minutes ago the honourable member for the Northern Territory indulged in an attack on the poor, defenceless Opposition. I will reciprocate with an attack on the Hawke Government. If one is born in the Australian Capital Territory, goes to school in the Australian Capital Territory and wants to go on to higher education, one has three times more chance of making it than if one goes through secondary school in Queensland. I believe that the Federal Government has deprived and thieved from the young people of Queensland. It has deprived them of opportunities of higher education. The money must be going somewhere.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—The shadow Minister at the table, the honourable member for Dawson, said, `Hear, hear!'. One suspects that the money is being poured into New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia, Western Australia and the Australian Capital Territory. Because Queensland has gone through a period of having a rather extraordinary, I might say, non-Labor government, its young people have been made to suffer and bear the burden as a form of punishment. TALK.START.PARA: —At the risk of boring the House, I will return to the purpose of the Commonwealth Teaching Service Amendment Bill and that is to amend the Commonwealth Teaching Service Act in line with a number of procedures on which the Government is keen in the areas of promotion, transfers, appeals, forfeiture of office and attachment of salary, as well as the transfer of certain teaching staff. That leaves efficiency as the one determinant, and rightly so. The definition of efficiency, I might add, has also been broadened to give the relevant authority the potential to consider an applicant's future career development and/or his raw native abilities for other duties at the same level. Also, we will have a component which provides the option of promoting or transferring an officer on the advice of a joint selection committee comprising an independent chairperson and two or three other members as agreed between the authority and the union.

The appeal process itself has been streamlined by removing the need for a promotions appeal tribunal, which is characteristic of so many Public Service situations. A person shall not be appointed-
I emphasise, `shall not be appointed'-
under paragraph (1) (b) unless the relevant staff organisation consents to the appointment of that person.

If that particular person was not a union member it is more than obvious that the relevant staff organisation would not give that consent. That is the first step. However, we do not believe it is not necessary to have consultation with the relevant staff organisation. Therefore we intend that proposed new section 32 (1) (b) would read:

I return to my concern for compulsory unionism in Australia. DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN AIRLINES (CONVERSION TO PUBLIC COMPANY) BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 18 February.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DUNCAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment and Education Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Following agreement of both Houses of Parliament, notice of termination of the 1981 airlines agreement was issued on 30 October 1987. An essential element of the deregulation environment after termination of the two airlines agreement will be a strong, viable and efficient Australian Airlines which will be able to provide effective competition across the trunk route network. The Bill now before the House represents an important first step in the process of preparing Australian for its future role by: establishing the airline as a public company; providing for reorganisation of the airline into a more appropriate structure prior to incorporation; and removing detailed Government controls on the airline's operations.

The legislation will establish the airline as a company in the most efficient way possible, by providing for the Commission to be deemed to be a company incorporated under the Companies Act 1981 on a day to be proclaimed. Secondly, the legislation provides for a reorganisation of the Commission prior to deeming. The Commission is seeking to establish a group structure which provides it with maximum flexibility to prepare for the more competitive environment facing the airline over the next few years and following deregulation. The legislation therefore makes provision for the reorganisation of the Commission prior to incorporation to ensure that the new company can operate from the outset on a proper commercial basis. Thirdly, the legislation provides for removal of existing statutory controls on the airline which are embodied in the Australian National Airlines Act 1945 through deletion of all substantive sections of that Act. The removal of these statutory controls will occur at the time of deeming the airline to be a company. As announced previously, the Government is giving consideration to the scope for removal of other broader controls, such as subjection of borrowings to Loan Council, in the context of the structural adjustment committee. Decisions on these controls are expected to be taken in the near future. I now wish to address the major provisions in the Bill in more detail.
Deeming

The Bill provides in Part IV for the conversion of the Australian National Airlines Commission to a public company. In particular, Clause 15 deems the Commission to have been immediately before the transition, and to be, at the transition a corporation within the meaning of the Companies Act and provides for the Commission to be registered as a company under the Australian Capital Territory Companies legislation. A major benefit of the deeming approach is that the company maintains the same corporate entity as the Commission. Because there is no change in the corporate entity there is no need: to transfer assets and liabilities from the Commission to a new body corporate; for novation of overseas contracts of the Commission, because there would be no new party to those contracts; to transfer any tax losses or the benefit of capital gains tax exemptions for pre-20 September 1985 assets to a new corporation; or for any change to existing Commonwealth loan guarantees, which would remain in place. The deeming approach therefore avoids the administrative costs and time which would be involved in resolving these matters under alternative legislative approaches.

All contracts, agreements and arrangements entered into by or on behalf of the Commission and which are in force immediately before transition, including the 1981 airlines agreement, will apply to the deemed company. All the shares in the deemed company will be held either directly by the Commonwealth, or by a Commonwealth wholly owned holding company.
Staffing Matters Related to Conversion

On transition each staff member of the Commission will become an employee of the company on the same terms and conditions as applied to his or her employment by the Commission. Entitlements such as long service and recreation leave, and eligibility for sick leave, will be preserved. There will be no entitlement to any payments in lieu of leave entitlements. The legislation enables the company to become a `prescribed authority' for purposes of the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act 1971. Those staff who have rights under the repealed Officers Rights Declaration Act 1928, or Part IV of the Public Service Act 1922 will retain those rights.

On transition the existing provisions covering superannuation for staff who are members of the Commonwealth superannuation scheme-(some 950 employees-will be maintained and the company will become an `approved authority' for the purposes of the Superannuation Act 1976. These provisions are necessary to avoid any industrial difficulties which could arise if the terms and conditions of staff on transition were left open.

The airline has proposed that, as a corporation, and subject to industrial agreement, it should have the ability to withdraw from the Commonwealth superannuation scheme and to transfer CSS staff to existing airline plans. This proposal is to be considered by the structural adjustment committee. The timing of conversion to a public company does not need to be decided at this stage. However it is expected that the transition will take place on 31 March 1988.
Company Structure

The airline has indicated it wishes to reorganise its activities into a holding company/subsidiary company structure, and views this as an essential part of the changes required in establishing the airline as a fully competitive public company, and to avoid any adverse legacy of its previous statutory authority form. This new structure would also allow greater devolution of management responsibilities and assist management to focus on activities where performance may need to be improved.

The Bill provides flexibility in the way in which the final group structure is to be achieved. One such way would be for the deemed company to assume the role of holding company. The other would be for the new holding company to be incorporated by the Commonwealth and for the deemed company to become a subsidiary undertaking the major airline operation activities.
Staff Matters Related to the Reorganisation

The Bill, by amending the appropriate provisions of applicable legislation, enables new companies created before commencing day as part of the group reorganisation, also to be covered by the provisions of the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act 1971 and the Long Service Leave (Commonwealth Employees) Act 1976. Where existing employees of the Commission are contributors to the Commonwealth superannuation scheme or have rights relating to Public Service employment under the repealed Offices Rights Declaration Act 1928 and part IV of the Public Service Act 1922, those rights and entitlements will also be preserved irrespective of transfer to any company in the group.
Transfers of Assets and Liabilities

Given that there will be no change in beneficial ownership by the Commonwealth, all transfers of assets and liabilities from the Commission to other companies within the group as part of this reorganisation, and for any related transfer of shares, should not be subject to Commonwealth, State and Territory taxes and duties. The Bill therefore provides for transfers to be exempt from such taxes and duties but restricts these exemptions, to transfers related directly to the reorganisation which takes place within the period between royal asset and transition day.
Taxation

The Bill will also ensure that the group reorganisation will be `tax neutral', with the overall taxation position of the companies involved being the same as would otherwise have applied to the Commission.
Removal of Government Controls

In his statement of 7 October 1987 outlining the Government's domestic aviation policy, the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) announced the removal of a number of day-to-day controls over Australian Airline's commercial operations to help streamline management decision making and place increased responsibility with the airline's board where it properly belongs. These controls included: all but exceptionally significant expenditure decisions, for example those requiring additional equity capital; detailed terms and conditions of borrowings and leasing arrangements; investment of surplus moneys; choice of auditor; dividend recommendations; and provision for insurance against risk. The deletion of all substantive sections of the Australian National Airlines Act 1945 will give effect to the Government's decision.

Further, as indicated earlier, the Government through the Structural Adjustment Committee will be examining the scope for removal of other broader controls over Australian Airlines' operations. These controls include:
Loan Council borrowing limits;
Remuneration Tribunal determination of board member and senior executive salaries;
Industrial relations arrangements being subject to Government oversight and co-ordination;
Restrictions on superannuation arrangements; and
Application of the offsets policy to purchases of aircraft and related spares.

Once the position on the broader controls has been settled, the Government will address the form of memorandum and articles of association, together with appropriate guidelines to directors of the company to ensure that the airline continues to be subject to appropriate minimum levels of controls, and so that there is an ongoing basis for establishing the airline's financial target and corporate planning responsibilities previously contained in the Australian National Airlines Act 1945.
Intrastate Operations

It has been necessary to retain section 19a of the Australian National Airlines Act 1945 to enable the Commonwealth to hold shares in a company operating intrastate air services in those States to which that section applies-currently Queensland, Tasmania, New South Wales and Western Australia. The Bill ensures that a group company will be able to carry on business in all States and Territories under names which have been protected in accordance with provisions of the Bill.
Amendments to Related Legislation

As required by the proposed reorganisation, the Bill amends definitions in the Airlines Equipment Act 1958 and the Independent Air Fares Committee Act 1981, which play an integral role in the operation of the existing airlines agreement, to extend the application of those Acts to cover all companies in the reorganised group. Additional legislative provisions are necessary to apply the Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Act 1987 to the group of companies. For constitutional reasons these provisions will be contained in a separate Bill, which will be introduced separately in the House.
Financial Impact Statement

The Bill does not involve additional expenditure by the Commonwealth or additional revenue to the Commonwealth. The Bill provides for exemption from Commonwealth, State and Territory taxes on transfer of assets as part of the proposed reorganisation of the airline, in recognition of the fact that there will be no change in the Commonwealth's beneficial ownership.
Conclusion

In future, there will be greater opportunities for the aviation environment to become more competitive as aviation specific economic regulatory controls are removed. There have already been developments in the domestic aviation industry which impinge on the extent and form of future competition. Following the recent take- over of East-West Airlines by News Corporation Ltd and TNT Ltd, Australian Airlines faces the prospect of greater competition from, on the one hand, Ansett Airlines of Australia in traditional markets and, on the other, East-West Airlines in the growing price sensitive leisure and tourism markets. Australian Airlines is therefore confronted in all areas of the domestic market by strong commercial competitors backed by extensive financial resources.

In these circumstances, this Bill represents an important first step on the part of the Government towards improved competitiveness of the airline by giving the management of Australian the flexibility to structure the airline in the most effective manner to meet the current and future challenges and the ability to run the airline without the hindrance of detailed bureaucratic controls. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the contribution that we have just heard from the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale), the shadow spokesman on aviation matters, a number of challenges were issued both personally to me and to other Government members in general to rebut some comments that have been made in previous contributions on aviation policy in this place by members of the Government.
