SPEECH.PARA: Because we are talking about one of the most important and fundamental public enterprises that are operating in Australia today-that is Australian Airlines-we need to look at the contribution that this airline makes to the Australian economy. The honourable member for Deakin made some comments about how this Government has miserably treated Australian Airlines, how the airline needs an injection of funds and comments of that nature. In fact during 1986-87 Australian Airlines carried something like five million passengers and had a turnover of $878m. If one looks at its record over the last couple of years in terms of the profits it has generated, one can see that in 1983-84 the net profit of Australian Airlines, or Trans-Australia Airlines as it was then, was a mere $3.9m. In 1985-86 that figure increased to $37.8m. In 1986-87 it was reduced to $24.9m because of one-off losses that were associated with the closure of the Air Queensland subsidiary. So, taking all that into consideration, we are talking about a rather significant contributor to the Australian economy. Australian Airlines is a major employer with some 9,600 employees being associated with it. As I have indicated, the airline makes a significant contribution to the revenue which is generated for the Government.

A point was raised with respect to the need for an injection of capital for Australian Airlines. Pre-1983, Australian Airlines was in an absolutely decimated condition. I put to the honourable member for Deakin that that was probably a result of several decades of policies followed by a variety of governments with respect to Australia's aviation industry. I am talking here about the two-airline policy, and I will say a little more about that in a moment. Quite clearly, Australian Airlines, which is owned by the Australian people, was being allowed to run down. All that changed in 1983. A decision was taken to inject capital into Australian Airlines. Indeed, $25m was approved by the previous coalition Government out of a total of something like $115m. So quite clearly, there was a recognition by this Government of the need to inject further capital into Australian Airlines to enable it to remain viable and meet commitments which existed under the two-airline policy.

The two-airline policy is quite interesting because the grandfather clause relating to it was put in place not by this Government but by a previous coalition Government-by the people who are now talking down the fact that there is a two-airline policy and that changes need to be made in a deregulated environment. Although this Government has, in fact, as a result of the May Independent Review of Economic Regulation of Domestic Aviation, made a considered response and has given formal notice that Australian Airlines and Ansett Airlines of Australia will have to terminate the two-airline policy, we still get the nonsense being spoken that we need in some way still to prop up Australian Airlines because of the coming deregulated environment.

It is fact-and the honourable member for Deakin quoted from some documents which had been drafted in response to requests from within the Australian Labor Party-that there is a need for capital injection for the future. No-one can dispute that. I find myself in agreement with the honourable member when he says that he does not want to see a monopoly or a one-airline policy in this country. I agree 100 per cent with that. In fact, it has been mooted in a variety of circles that perhaps one way we could get around that, one way in which we could see Australian Airlines operated in a more efficient manner than it presently is, would be an amalgamation with Qantas Airways Ltd. I raise that as an issue-one publicly owned company, Qantas and Australian together, competing against Ansett at the moment and, after deregulation in 1990, against whatever small or larger companies might come on the scene.

I notice that the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) is shaking his head about that as an option. I am not suggesting for one moment that it is an option that will be followed, but I am suggesting to him that it is an option that is being discussed freely within the community. It raises some interesting points because it goes to the support that came some months ago when the whole privatisation debate was under way whereby Ansett, for example, was supportive of the privatisation of Australian Airlines. It said, `What a great idea; put it in the public forum. Let's have capital injection going in from private enterprise'. There was the myth of Australian people buying into it. How can they buy into something which they already own? I find that terribly difficult to understand. Those were some of the views that were put around.

Very quickly, that view was changed and was turned around when somebody suggested that one way we could get around it was for Qantas to take over Australian Airlines. With its bigger aircraft-jumbos-and capacity to operate around Australia, one can imagine the effect it would have on Ansett. That may not be a reasonable solution to the problem. It may not even stand the test of time or the test of scrutiny as to whether it is economically feasible, but nevertheless it is an issue that has been raised. I wonder whether, in their examination of the whole series of issues that have been raised in privatisation debates and so on, those Opposition members who are supportive of this would care to look into that in some detail.

The Australian Airlines (Conversion to Public Company) Bill which is before us this evening, proposes to convert Australian Airlines to a public company for a variety of reasons. The honourable member for Deakin went to great lengths to point out that similar legislation was put in place by the previous Government, that the present Government saw fit to change it and that now we are going back to an original proposition which is not altogether different from what had been put in place. I have said in this House on a number of occasions that I do not find a great deal of difficulty in accepting that, if facts can be put before a government of the day which suggest that a decision taken a number of years previously perhaps is no longer suitable for the climate of the day, that decision should be altered. I have no problem in going out and selling that decision on behalf of the Government. I have no problem in going out into the marketplace and saying: `Australian Airlines is to be converted to a public company to remove some of the constraints that might exist for a statutory authority or a public enterprise of some description'. I have no worries about that at all. I am sure, having heard the contribution of the honourable member for Deakin, that he has no real worries about it either. He has moved an amendment, but the terms of the amendment are simply to press home some perceived political advantage in this. I think it is important when we talk about Australian Airlines becoming a public company to give some thought to those people working in the airline industry. We have to give some thought also to Mr James Strong, the Managing Director of Australian Airlines, who was brought in some years ago to give it a lift, to try to make it more competitive with Ansett. We have to talk about some of the other people who have turned around the management enterprises of, as some would say, a tired old flagship of Australian aviation. We have seen the results of that. We can see, as the honourable member for Deakin indicated through reference to a document on Australian Airlines-a discussion paper by Senator Gareth Evans, the Minister for Transport and Communications, dated February 1988-that there is a need for an injection of some $1 billion and additional funds to come after that, because the replacement of the Airbus and other types of aircraft does not come cheap. The Bill, as I have indicated, establishes a public company incorporated under the Companies Act 1981. It does a number of other things as well. I have no real objection to that. The airline itself remains within the ownership of the people of Australia. It is Australian-owned already. It is seen as the government airline but, nevertheless, it is owned for and on behalf of the people of Australia. As the Minister for Employment and Education Services (Mr Duncan) pointed out in his second reading speech, recent developments in the industry, which impinge on the extent and form of future competition, mean in some respects that there is a need for strong commercial competitors backed by extensive financial resources. That is exactly what the Government proposes here.

The honourable member for Deakin put forward an amendment to the motion that the Bill be read a second time. The amendment was in five parts. The first talked about the double standards of this Government in introducing legislation. I have made some comments about that. In my view, if circumstances change and there has been a major review of the airline industry, which there has-the May Independent Review of Economic Regulation of Domestic Aviation was a major review of the airline industry in this country and the findings of that have substantiated the view that there was a need to make Australian Airlines a public company and divorce it from its present controls-I have no worries with supporting such legislation.
The second part of the amendment-this is where I find myself at great odds with the honourable member for Deakin-states:
its failure to take into account the recommendations of the Advisory Group on Australian Airline's future capital requirements;

In my view, the honourable member for Deakin maligned the members of that review group by suggesting that their riding instructions had already been published through the release of a document which was to be a Caucus discussion document on the future of Australian Airlines and an number of options that might exist. What people in this place have to get into their minds is that when experts in their field, whether industrial relations, aviation policy or whatever-as I believe are represented on the review committee-are drawn together, one should not automatically assume that they will report in a way which is predisposed to reflecting predetermined government policy or outcome. I believe, as I have indicated, that the honourable member for Deakin has maligned those people on that committee. As he indicated, the report has not yet been released. The Committee is not due to hand down its recommendations for another few weeks. Yet he went to great pains to say that, because of the make-up of that committee, it will simply reinforce what is contained in the document and that that will reinforce what is contained in the legislation before us tonight.

The third point which the honourable member for Deakin raised in his amendment concerned the privatisation issue. Obviously, this is an issue which has exercised the minds of all honourable members for the last couple of years. I have spoken in a number of debates on privatisation. I would have preferred that the honourable member for Deakin had quoted in full any questions I may have directed to the Minister of the time responsible for aviation when he chose to quote selectively from some of the answers that were given to my questions. He may have found that what I proposed and what I was attempting to draw from the then Minister's answers reflected personal views that I hold on privatisation in general but particularly privatisation of Australian Airlines. I do not believe that there has been any failure on the part of this Government to make up its mind on privatising Australian Airlines. Quite simply, it is an issue that is fundamental to this political party. It will go through all the forums available for discussion and determination before a final policy is arrived at. We believe that is the most appropriate and democratic way of doing so.

The fourth amendment refers to unnecessary uncertainty among Australian Airlines employees as to their future. Personally, I believe that is rubbish; that is an emotive part of the amendment put in perhaps to frighten some people. On this side of the House we have seen how those sorts of issues are thrown up from time to time with the specific aim of frightening certain groups in the community. We have heard about reds under the beds, and hiding one's money under one's bed because the Government might take it. We have have heard a whole range of other diatribes trotted out at various times. None of them have come true, and I see no reason why this particular issue will come true either.

Finally, reference was made to continuing poor administration of Australia's aviation infrastructure. If there has been such poor administration of Australia's aviation infrastructure, how is it that there has been major developments of Brisbane Airport, upgrading of Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport-not before time, the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) would say-and other improvements around Australia at different locations. As I have said, there has been an injection of capital into Australian Airlines; the purchase of modern equipment by Australian Airlines and by Ansett Airlines of Australia; a major review of the aviation industry embarked upon in this country; and the determination that a deregulated environment would best suit Australia's needs into the future; and so on. Quite clearly, I do not believe that the proposition put forward by the honourable member for Deakin in his contribution tonight can be sustained in any way.

In conclusion I say that this legislation deals with a fundamental position that the Government advocates. That fundamental position is that Australian Airlines is a public company, owned by Australians, and operated by Australians. The talk that there is in some way a need for privatisation is being thrown up at the present time simply because of the times and the economic circumstances in which we find ourselves. I have said that one option that might be available, the amalgamation of Australian Airlines and Qantas Airways Ltd, might provide some economic rationality to this argument. However, that amalgamation might result in something that is too super-big or too superefficient, which in some respects would frighten the living daylights out of some honourable gentlemen on the other side of the House.

Nevertheless, this legislation will guarantee that under a conversion to a public company, the employees will be protected, as will their rights. The legislation will guarantee that the company can operate more effectively and, more important, take responsibility for the management decisions of the board which, after all, is appointed to regulate the operations of Australian Airlines. For all those reasons I believe that the legislation should be supported. I certainly hope that I have been able to rise to the challenge issued by my friend on the other side of the House, the honourable member for Deakin, and answer some of the questions that he raised in the debate tonight. Though I am sure that some honourable members on this side of the House might like to, I cannot bring myself to support the amendment proposed by the honourable gentleman. Therefore I commend the legislation as it stands to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be very easy for me tonight to take some joy in the embarrassment that obviously is being felt by the Government in introducing this particular legislation tonight, especially in the light of its history. As we have heard from both contributors to the debate, in 1981 this legislation was introduced by the then Liberal-National Party Government. In 1984 it was withdrawn by the Labor Party Government. In 1987 it was re-introduced; and in 1988 we are debating it. As I say, we can make great political capital out of that, and I suppose we will all feel good about it. However, the sad point is that this legislation is at least seven years too late, and the only people who have been affected by it have been the long-suffering public who, quite frankly, for the past seven years, have had to pay far too much for their domestic air fares.

SPEECH.PARA: We should really return to the very roots of the problem that we have in the domestic aviation scene today-to the establishment of Trans Australia Airlines (TAA), as it was then called, in 1945. The honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) was perfectly correct. Although he did not go into great detail, he did allude to the fact that one of the big problems in the Australian aviation industry has been the undercapi- talisation of TAA-now Australian Airlines. That problem goes back to 1945. After that there was the emergence of the two airlines system in the early 1950s. There was sufficient protection then for both airlines to survive. However, by the mid-1970s the market was right to be opened up to provide some competition in Australia. However, no government was prepared to take it on at that time. In 1976, not long after I entered this House, I can remember in a speech putting forward the proposition that the privatisation of TAA-as it then was-really was the only way we could proceed if we were to have true competition and truly competitive air fares in Australia for, as I have said, the long suffering Australian travelling public.

In 1981 another two airlines agreement Bill was introduced. Quite proudly, on that occasion I voted against my Government. My friend, the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack) was one of the 13, I believe, who crossed the floor against the Government on that night, because of the solid recognition that something had to change. We said that we did not want that legislation, and we went very close to defeating it. That was seven years ago. Today we are still no closer to being able to introduce a truly competitive airline system.

One of the sad things that resulted from the under capitalisation of TAA and Australian Airlines has simply been the fact that air fares in this country have for so long been set on the least efficient operator in the industry. Not necessarily through any fault of its own, that has fallen on the TAA-Australian Airlines combination of recent years. The fares have had to be set that way, and in fact we have created a very soft and comfortable featherbed for Australian Airlines' major competitor, Ansett Airlines.

That is certainly not intended to deride the performance of Ansett, which has proven itself to be one of the great airlines of the world. One must pay due regard to the tremendous expansion that Ansett Airlines has undertaken in the past eight or nine years, since the takeover of that particular company by TNT and News Ltd. That takeover has expanded Ansett Airlines to a point where it now effectively has 60 per cent of the aviation business in Australia; it has one of the biggest worldwide aviation leasing companies; it is operating airlines around the world; and it now holds a major stake of some 20 per cent in American West Airlines. As a result, Australia really has been able to make itself felt in world aviation circles. Unfortunately TAA has been restricted, Australian Airlines has been restricted, and the people who have suffered have been the travelling public of Australia.

We have heard arguments from the honourable member for Macarthur as to what we must do. He has also admitted that there must be a major injection of capital into Australian Airlines. As I say, that company really has been undercapitalised since 1945. The honourable member for Macarthur spoke of large sums of money, for example $250m. That particular injection could well end up coming out of the pockets of the taxpayers of Australia. Other funds have been injected into TAA to try to get it to the situation where it could be competitive. A few years ago I remember that we had to bolster TAA's superannuation fund, to keep it viable. That money came out of the pockets of the taxpayers. There was really no necessity for this situation to evolve.

What really scared the socks off me in the speech by the honourable member for Macarthur was the proposition that perhaps one solution would be an amalgamation of Qantas Airways Ltd and Australian Airlines. Apart from the fact that Senator Gareth Evans said that that amalgamation is not on, I suggest that the honourable member for Macarthur should make a study of the aviation industry overseas. One of the greatest debacles in the aviation industry in the early 1970s was the amalgamation of the then British Overseas Airways Corporation and British European Airways. That involved two government instrumentalities, an international operator and virtually a domestic operator operating within Europe, come together with all the problems that that created, including separate reservation systems.

We had a situation in which the then British Airways, as the combine became known, was overstaffed to the tune of almost 30,000. Over the years it has been a very painful procedure for British Airways to cut back on its staff numbers until it got to the stage where it now has between 25,000 and 29,000 staff. That airline lost hundreds and hundreds of millions of pounds over the years trying to get itself into some semblance of order. It really did not get itself into some semblance of order until the infrastructure was set up to enable the whole British airline system to be privatised. That process is under way now and British Airways is one of the most highly profitable airlines in the world. It has taken the airline about 17 or 18 years to get to that point and as a government-owned instrumentality it could not achieve that. It had to get out into the private sector in order to achieve flexibility-the capacity to get capital and the capacity to make good business decisions in order to run as a viable commercial enterprise before it got back on top. Now, of course, it is beginning to do very well indeed.

It is interesting that around the world there are major airlines that have been government-owned but which are now going out to be privatised because that is the future. Close to home, there is Singapore Airlines Ltd. Look at what that airline has done in the international market with those business principles and the flexibility that they have provided. Look what is happening in Malaysia and Thailand. Look what is happening in Korea. Look what has happened to Japan Air Lines, which also had the dead hand of government sitting on it for so long. Now Japan Air Lines is out there; it is being privatised and is becoming most competitive. A whole new regime, including one for air fares, is coming into the Japanese market, which was one of the most highly regulated in aviation history.

I do not believe that there is any real chance for an amalgamation of Qantas and Australian Airlines to work in a market such as Australia because of the two airlines comparative sizes. I hope that we do not look at that possibility. In fact, it would be very difficult to bring that about. One of the most fascinating amalgamations in recent times-and Australian Airlines has been caught in this regard too-has been the coming together of Ansett Airlines and Qantas. They have a commercial agreement to share reservations offices around the world. One can well imagine that most of the domestic travel that is booked through those Qantas offices around the world goes to Ansett. It certainly does not go to Australian Airlines. I know that Australian Airlines has some tie-up with Air New Zealand Ltd. Although that is a very good predator airline, it is still pretty small fry. If one were able to obtain the figures it would be very interesting to compare how much money Air New Zealand is pouring into Australian Airlines vis-a-vis how much goes from the Qantas offices world wide into Ansett and vice versa. Thus, the amalgamation of Qantas and Australian is really not a proposition for this country.

Although this legislation is being welcomed now, it is far too late. We have paid too much money for our domestic air fares for a long time now. I was delighted to hear the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) refer to the elevation of Mr James Strong as General Manager of Australian Airlines. James Strong has been like a breath of fresh air through that organisation. I have spoken to him at some length over some of the difficulties he encountered in taking over an operation such as that airline-the difficulties he has had in getting Australian Airlines onto the best commercial basis, the very real problems he had in the industrial relations field and in getting recognition by some of the staff--

TALK.START.PARA: —We are not going to get a second reading response, are we? We asked for it but now the Minister is leaving the chamber.

—The Minister is walking out; that is really a bit sad because it illustrates the contempt that this Government shows on an issue as vital as this. We can only be sorry that the Minister for Transport and Communications Support (Mr Peter Morris) is away ill this week because I would have been delighted to hear some of his responses in the light of his previous comments. James Strong has tried hard and I believe that if we can get a commercial set up for Australian Airlines it might have some remote chance of competing.

SPEECH.PARA: My real concern is that the neglect of the Australian domestic airline scene has gone so far now that it might be almost impossible to get any real sense of competition back into that market. Ansett Airlines has effectively 60 per cent of the business at present. Australian Airlines is in there and it is trying very hard. This legislation is part of the overall program to ensure that when we get into the 1990s and the two-airline agreement finishes, we can have open competition in the Australian market. Is that too late too? Will any other carrier have the capacity to get into that market when we have such a tight closed shop?

The Government should also be condemned because, in delaying this legislation, it has caused a real problem for Australian Airlines in its re-equipment program. Some years ago it put in an initial order with Airbus Industrie for the supply of a number of A320 aircraft to replace the ageing fleet of 727s. This order was worth about $650m. It included a whole lot of infrastructure that was required for the introduction of a new aircraft type. That order has now been cancelled. Ansett has its A320s coming into Australia in August and September of this year. Once again we have that remarkable situation of some years ago where, in a commercial or advertising sense, Ansett had the capacity to completely denigrate the TAA DC9s with its new 737 technology. This had a tremendous effect on the travelling public. What will happen now? Will Australian Airlines be saddled with the label `second best' because it does not have the capacity to re-equip? It is to the Government's shame that it has allowed this legislation to lapse for so long. It should have been brought in at least seven years ago.

I refer to a couple of points made by the honourable member for Macarthur when he gave his justification for the non-privatisation of government instrumentalities. The reason that we have such high air fares is not necessarily just the monopoly situation or the particular financial situation in which Australian Airlines finds itself. The whole infrastructure of Australia needs some radical changing. I am not convinced, as yet, that we will get it with the new Airports Authority. I wonder whether some of the more far-searching people on the Government benches may be looking towards the privatisation of aerodromes. The honourable member for Macarthur rightly mentioned the disaster that is Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. Everybody acknowledges the very real difficulties there.

We all know the debate that is going on about the new Brisbane Airport, which, incidentally, was a Liberal Party initiative that went back to 1969. It was cancelled by the Whitlam Labor Government in 1973 and brought back by the Liberals in 1977. The airport is now being constructed without an international terminal. It is really quite sad. But the potential is there for new projects, such as Brisbane Airport, to loosen up and get rid of the dead hand of the bureaucracy. I think there is a very good argument for Australia looking at the possibility of privatising our international airports. We can see what has been achieved in the United States of America and even in Great Britain, with an airport such as Manchester. Those airports have got away from the civil aviation authorities of those countries and have been allowed to go out there in a commercial sense and compete with other airports around the world. They have been able to provide infrastructure, which is very much high financing of the operations of a particular airport. If we look at these airports we get some indication of what we could achieve in Australia if we had this major revolution in the aviation industry. If some of the more far-searching members of the Government benches turned their minds to what could happen, we could see some real cost savings as a result of privatising those airports. I sincerely hope that future Liberal governments would look at bringing our airport operations into the 1990s and to the year 2000 and beyond by allowing them to open up so that we never have a situation such as the one we have in Sydney, or the one in Brisbane at the moment with the bungling that has gone on there.

I also say that I support the amendment moved by the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale), this evening. There is no doubt that ultimately Australian Airlines, if it is going to survive, will have to be privatised. It will have to be privatised if it is going to get the capital and have the full capacity to go out and compete in a very tight market. There has also been some uncertainty among Australian Airlines employees about what their future might really be. It is interesting to talk not only to the most senior members of Australian Airlines but also to quite a number of the less senior staff who are saying that they recognise that there has to be privatisation of Australian Airlines if it is to reach its full potential. I was at a function last Friday night and speaking to some middle management people of Australian Airlines. They brought that home to me very clearly indeed. They stated outright that what they wanted to see was a complete loosening up of Australian Airlines so it could be privatised to enable it to go out and compete and not have to be second best, as it is perceived to be at the moment.

The fifth part of the second reading amendment moved by the honourable member for Deakin concerning the continuing poor administration of Australian Airlines infrastructure is so true. I mentioned the situation at airports. We can see the same situation in regard to maintenance, all the way down. Unless we get some very clear guidelines on how the Federal Airports Corporation is to operate, unless we get some very real innovation into the administration of the aviation industry in Australia, I do not think that we will see a day when the Australian travelling public get that fair deal. There is an expectation in the community that we should be getting to a stage where people can travel more cheaply than they are travelling at the moment. People acknowledge that the two airlines system is binding things up. People are concerned that the takeover of East-West Airlines Ltd could well mean that the only alternative to the two majors will be swallowed up. I think that the real condemnation of the air fare regime in Australia and the restrictions that have been placed on the domestic aviation industry is registered in one simple fact: only 14 per cent of Australians have flown.

TALK.START.PARA: —Only 14 per cent?

—I think perhaps 14.7 per cent of people have been in an aircraft. If we look at the reasons why that remaining 85 per cent of people have not been in aircraft the biggest factor is cost-and no other reason. Unless we get those costs down we will not see the full utilisation of our infrastructure. We will not see the capacity of Australian Airlines to expand fulfilled. We will not see the most useful utilisation of the airline services. After all, here in Australia, flying is an essential; it is not a luxury any more. What we must do in this place is to make sure we have the infrastructure in place to provide an efficient, safe and relatively inexpensive form of travel for the Australian public.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Thursday last this House was treated to a rather unusual situation when the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) rose to make a statement in connection with the progress report on the new Parliament House. SPEECH.PARA: The new material raised by the Minister in his second speech was in connection with the rainforest timbers from north Queensland and what was happening with the progress of the new Parliament House in that respect. I suggest that there is a history in connection with the questioning of the Parliament House Construction Authority on the effect of the ban on rainforest timbers. For instance, a rather lengthy question was asked in the Senate on 18 December. It contained many parts in connection with compensation, additional costs and whether timber would be imported as an alternative. The Minister for Home Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) replied that he could not give an answer, but that he would seek advice from the Minister for Administrative Services in the other place and provide the information later. The Minister did not then address himself to the question of the additional cost. The other matter about which information was sought which the Minister refused to give was the additional cost in connection with ascertaining whether the timber was logged and machined before or after 11 August. TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to draw to the attention of the Parliament a very serious incident involving a young man working on a rural cattle property in south-west Queensland which will probably shock those listening because of its similarity to the recent Western Australian tragedy involving two young station hands, Simon Amos and James Annetts, which is the subject of the current Kununurra inquest.

SPEECH.PARA: My office was in contact at the end of last week with Mr Roger Brown, the father of Matthew Brown, the 17-year-old young man involved in the incident. Some six weeks ago Matthew applied for a job as a station hand on the cattle property `Nockatunga', which is some 100 kilometres west of Thargomindah in the south-west of Queensland. A business names search has revealed that this property is owned by Nockatunga Pastoral Co. which in turn is owned by Simon Gore, Harold Hughes and Christopher Hughes, all of South Australia.

Matthew was no doubt attracted by the image of rugged individualism and adventure associated with working as a station hand-the same image which lures many inexperienced people to the bush at what is really still a very young age. Matthew's father is acutely aware of this, as he himself is a property owner-fortunately a more responsible employer than the Hugheses and Mr Gore.

Matthew made it abundantly clear in his written application that he had very limited experience on the land and was told over the telephone that this was not a problem. He commenced work on 8 January this year. During Matthew's first week of work the manager left and the property was left in the care of a neighbour. On the morning of 12 January, a mere four days later, Matthew was directed to go with another employee to repair a water pump on the property. The other uncoupled a polythene pipe, but did not warn Matthew that there may be the possibility of an escape of boiling water under pressure. This did happen and Matthew received serious burns to this stomach, both thighs, his groin and right arm. Matthew was fortunate, if you could call it that, because at the time he was crouching over. Had it not been for that, he may have lost his sight.

It is incredible to think that the manager of a property would leave a 17-year-old boy to do dangerous work like that, in the company of someone who obviously did not know what he was doing. It is even more incredible to think that the owners of the property allow that sort of work practice to exist on their property. The circumstances surrounding the accident itself are atrocious in the degree of negligence shown, but the details of Matthew's treatment after the accident are approaching criminal. It was the sort of treatment that you would have expected to find in an eighteenth century English sweatshop, not twentieth century Australia. He was taken back to the workers quarters, but no medical attention was offered. At Matthew's request a paramedic was summoned from the nearby Jackson oilfield. According to Matthew the people on the property showed little interest in his condition and it was only at the insistence of the Jackson oilfield paramedic that Matthew was flown to Brisbane for urgent medical treatment for second and third degree burns.

It is worthy to note that it was the paramedic from the Jackson oilfield who accompanied Matthew to Brisbane. Neither the manager nor anyone else from the property bothered to travel to Brisbane with Matthew.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shocking.

—It is shocking, as the honourable Member for Fisher points out. The Jackson oilfield paramedic commented to Matthew's father that it was the worst case of neglect of an employee that he had ever encountered. This is a serious claim coming from a medical officer who works on an oilfield and who would see hundreds of injuries each year.

SPEECH.PARA: Madam Speaker, not only has the pastoral company refused to complete the necessary documentation for Matthew to obtain workers compensation, which is every worker's right, but it has also refused to pay Matthew for the days worked prior to the accident. In fact, the Workers Compensation Board in Toowoomba has written to the Nockatunga Pastoral Co. on no fewer than three occasions and has not even received a reply or acknowledgment of the letter. Neither the Hugheses nor Mr Gore, the owners of the Nockatunga Pastoral Co., have even had the common decency to phone and inquire about Matthew's health at the time of the accident or subsequently. So not only was Matthew treated badly immediately after the accident occurred but as well the people responsible for this shameful treatment do not even appear to be in the least bit concerned about the pain and suffering they have caused, physically to Matthew and emotionally to his family. As a point of interest, Madam Speaker, I am informed that the agent for Nockatunga Pastoral Co. is Elders Pastoral, a subsidiary company of the giant Elders IXL group headed by none other than the Federal President of the Liberal Party of Australia, Mr John Elliott. The scandalous treatment of workers like animals, as in Matthew's case, is typical of deregulated industrial systems. This is the sort of industrial system advocated by the Opposition--

SPEECH.PARA: Government members-Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —I might say to the `hear, hears' of my colleagues opposite that it was excellent to see that exhibition centre open and in operation. It is fitting that for the first time the Skill Olympics should be held in the Southern Hemisphere in Australia's bicentennial year and in our premier city, Sydney. I rise tonight to say a few words about this event because it is worth talking about and publicising. The Skill Olympics is obviously not well known in this House or around the country.

SPEECH.PARA: What is the Skill Olympics? It is a trade competition between young people from countries around the world in much the same way as we have the sporting Olympics with which we are all familiar. The Skill Olympics work in this way: each event consists of carrying out a specified work project over a four-day period which is issued at the start of the competition. Each competitor is supplied with the same equipment and materials but uses his or her own tools. The competition projects have a set marking scale, with each component of the job contributing to the overall mark. The international panel of judges in each category spends two days examining the finished work. The measurements must be spot-on or else no marks are awarded.

At the twenty-ninth Skill Olympics currently going on in Sydney, with the prizes to be awarded this Wednesday, there are 34 work skill categories, with another 11 categories being demonstrated in the Sydney Olympics for the first time. There are 400 competitors from 19 nations and every day for the past couple of days skilled workers aged between 18 and 23 have been doing their very best in their respective fields. The fields of endeavour cover a wide range of trades, from automotive mechanics, bricklaying, cabinet making, carpentry, construction steel work right through to toolmaking, turning, waiting on tables and wood pattern making.

What was fascinating about the day that I was privileged to witness was to stand in that exhibition hall, look down from the mezzanine level and see these 400 competitors, in their roped off areas for their trades, going flat out competing against one another under the very keen and watchful eye of international judges. If that was significant, exciting and fascinating, what was even more exciting was the sight of probably 10,000 school children from Sydney and rural New South Wales who had the opportunity to visit the Skill Olympics walking down the aisles and alleyways watching their peers, who could not have been more than a couple of years older than them, competing in the Skill Olympics.

The Skill Olympics in Australia have been sponsored by the Work Skill Australia Foundation, which is an industry, corporation and union led organisation backed and supported by the Commonwealth and State governments. What is important is that a significant amount of its funding comes from both corporate and union Australia. The rationale behind Work Skill Australia is to promote the concepts of skill and excellence and promote the vocations that commonly occupy the trades as we understand them.

There is a great deal of work going on in Australia at the moment to increase and improve the participation rates in high school education. It is obvious that, as we increase those participation rates, not every young boy or girl will go on to university or college. Many will have their eyes opened for the first time to a vocational or trade career. The Skill Olympics, and the work of Work Skill Australia, are important in trying to lift the status of the vocational trades in Australia. We currently have a shortage of skilled trades men and women. We are resorting to migration, regrettably in that sense, to try to make up for our labour force deficiencies. We have a high rate of youth unemployment with something like 150,000 young people out of work and, if we can turn them to the trades, all the better.

Since the 1983-84 Budget, payments paid directly to Queensland local authorities by the Federal Government have increased from $5.98m to $24.2m in 1987-88. This is a massive increase in assistance to local government in Queensland. In per capita terms, Queensland local authorities received the highest direct payments of any State of $9.09 per capita, compared with an Australian total of $7.03 per capita.

SPEECH.PARA: Quite properly, from my point of view, Queensland local authorities appear to be being well assisted by the Federal Government. My concern is that this assistance is not being passed on to the communities for which it is intended. I refer to the National Inquiry into Local Government Finance, conducted by Professor Peter Self. Professor Self and his committee, which included Tony Philbrick, the former Town Clerk of Brisbane, who would have been a National Party candidate for the State seat of Sherwood and a National Party candidate at the last Federal election in the division of Forde--

TALK.START.PARA: —What went wrong?
—He forgot to nominate. He alluded to a briefing from the Department of Finance which said:

SPEECH.PARA: There is evidence that not only has the Commonwealth general purpose assistance led to a reduction in the real level of assistance to local government by those States (Queensland) but, for their own budgetary reasons, by increasing the taxes, duties and so on, that impact on local government of these States have further diminished the real resources available to local government authorities.

The Self committee then said that Queensland local government experienced a substantial increase in transfer payments to other government authorities from 1978-79 to 1982-83. Levies alone more than doubled in Queensland between 1978-79 and 1979-80 and continued their upward trend until 1981-82. The Committee then referred to a table entitled `Transfer Payments by Local Government to Other Government Authorities 1976-77 to 1982-83'. The table is quite revealing for Queensland. It shows that Queensland local authorities paid $6m to other government authorities in 1976-77 and this had climbed to $17m by 1982-83-an increase of a staggering 183.3 per cent. This compared with a minus figure in all other States except Victoria. So, under the Fraser Government, the Queensland National and Liberal State government in Queensland was engaged in the most blatant rip-off of the local government authorities in Queensland.

The reason I ask the Minister to investigate whether this is still happening is this: If such a scandal was perpetrated by the coalition against its own coalition Federal Government, we must consider what must be going on now that the National Party is governing in its own right. I have received many representations from local authorities in my own area calling for more Federal assistance. Who can blame them, especially when the Queensland Government appears to be engaged in usury? However, it is essential, in my view, if the Federal Government is to provide money to local authorities, that this money be of genuine assistance. It cannot and should not be a way of indirect payments to the States, as has clearly been the case in Queensland.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Much is spoken about the relationship between Asia and Australia, but there is an aspect that is never really discussed in this House. I would like to touch on it briefly tonight. I do not understand why the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) hates Queensland so much. He will probably be very temporary with it, but never mind. In the 25 years up to 1975, the total world population increased from just under 2,500 million to over 4,000 million. By the year 2000 it is expected to reach 6,200 million, of which four-fifths will be in the developing countries, with the substantial majority living in desperate poverty. We hear much talk in this House about Australia and its present situation, but I should imagine that the people of Asia would look at Australia and note that it is approaching a zero population growth rate, which it is expected to reach by the year 2000, and that we abort roughly 100,000 babies each year. There is even talk in some circles about euthanasia. So the people of Asia must look at Australia and ask themselves, `What really gives in that wonderful country?'.

SPEECH.PARA: When we think that of the four-fifths of the world's total population in the developing countries, many of them are living in substantial, desperate poverty, the implication of population increases are staggering. In the developing countries between now and the end of the century 800 million additional jobs will need to be created. We have heard the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack) talk about jobs in Australia and we have high unemployment, but when we think that 700 million additional jobs will need to be created in the developing countries, the thought is absolutely staggering. Millions of people must be affected by this. We read of and we see the desperate poverty in certain countries in Africa and we often ask ourselves what we can do. We hear of all the aid that is sent to those countries but we still see the misery and the number of people who die as a result of not having enough food to eat and, of course, no jobs.

In the developing countries, per capita consumption of resources, so much higher than in the developing world, has been the cause of much pollution, waste and environmental degradation. It has also contributed to worldwide shortages in resources. The problem is horrific. An increasing population means that more food and other resources necessary for people to live and survive are needed. Instead of evening out, the situation is going backwards rapidly. What can we do about it? Many people in Australia say that we should look after ourselves, that we have our own problems. They ask, `Why should we help anybody else?'. But this problem is getting so horrific and so close to us that I think we need to talk more about it.

Parliamentarians meet on occasions and talk about the world population. If we do not talk about it, all of a sudden one of these days, one of those countries may say, `Look Australia, you have a lot. You have more than enough; we want a bit of it'. That thought is staggering, too. Other countries could come after us. They could say, `We want it. If you do not give it to us we will take it by force'. We should always keep it in mind that there are many other people far worse off than we are. They need our help and attention and I think at times we should give it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable members will recall that in the adjournment of 7 December last I raised my concerns and those of many of my constituents regarding the possible introduction of an FM commercial radio station, its service area being the whole of the Latrobe Valley; in other words, a superstation which would gobble up the overlapping service areas of radio stations 3TR and 3UL but exclude the hinterland, if you like, of those existing service areas. Let me recap what I said, because it is an issue of tremendous importance to Gippslanders.

SPEECH.PARA: Gippsland is served principally by two commercial radio stations: 3UL, which has its station located at Warragul and has a large service area which takes in the Latrobe Valley; and 3TR, located at Sale, which takes in all of East Gippsland and the Latrobe Valley. The principal population body is centred in the Latrobe Valley. In other words, the major part of both those radio stations' service areas is centred in the Latrobe Valley. Therefore-I risk stating the obvious-the national advertisers particularly, as well as many of the larger local advertisers, direct their advertising to the Latrobe Valley. That is the situation in a nutshell.

The Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) indicated in a statement released on 3 October 1987 that it is the Government's intention to circulate planning information for a new commercial radio station in the Latrobe Valley in February 1990 and to call for applications in May of the same year. So there will be a new FM commercial radio station at some time, all things being equal, in 1990 or soon thereafter. My concern is that it will be centred in the Latrobe Valley and will take up as its service area an area not extending much beyond the La-trobe Valley. That will weaken, if not destroy, radio stations 3UL and 3TR on the AM band. Those radio stations must remain profitable and viable if the people in the far flung areas-south Gippsland, east Gippsland and west Gippsland-are to continue to be served. If this superstation is located only in the Latrobe Valley it will, to a very large extent, destroy 3UL and 3TR. It is a very simple problem, but this Minister has so far failed to address the concerns not just of myself, or for that matter of 3TR and 3UL, but also of many Gippslanders who live in the more remote areas who can see themselves, if a superstation is created in the Latrobe Valley, being deprived of commercial radio services.

It is a tremendously serious problem which I have raised before in this House and in correspondence with the various Ministers. There has been such a turnover, at least of junior Ministers, in the communications portfolio that it is difficult to get any sort of sensible reply from the Minister. Given the importance of the issue, I will, however, continue to raise the matter in the House. The Minister must reassure us that an FM commercial superstation will not be created with a service area only in the Latrobe Valley because of the effects that will have on 3TR and 3UL. By all means, the Government should require that the offices of the successful applicant for the FM licence be located in the Latrobe Valley, but it should not by any means draw up a service area to include only the La- trobe Valley. The successful applicant or applicants must have the same service areas as 3UL and 3TR if those two AM stations are to remain in existence and if all Gippslanders are to receive the same access to AM and FM commercial radio.

—We will be here for a long time so there will be plenty of opportunities to sort us out. I was not going to speak tonight but I thought I would take a brief moment, seeing that there was a little time to mention an event which took place last week that passed without comment by any member of this House. It was the tabling in this House of the 1986-87 report of the Department of Science. Interestingly enough, that was the last report of the Department of Science that will be tabled in the course of the Hawke Government. The Department of Science is now no longer and I think that fact needs to be lamented. In my role as spokesman for science I would, of course, have liked there to be a Department of Science that I could watch over and on which I could actively pursue the Minister. But we have a Minister for Science in name only in this Government and I think that fact needs to be lamented. While science is something that perhaps does not capture the minds of many of the journalists because we tend to deal with day to day matters in this chamber, it is one of those areas of government and, indeed, of human endeavour that is extremely important for the long term future of this country. Science, together with the other area of my responsibility, energy, which is in a similar vein to science I think, being more of a long term issue than a short term issue, is something that seems to have been downgraded.

SPEECH.PARA: Interestingly, all of the elements of the former Department of Science have been scattered to the four winds. We had in this country a Department of Science for some 15 years. Now it has gone. Vital bodies such as the Australian Institute of Marine Science have now gone to different departments. Many honourable members would be aware that Australia leads the world in astrophysics. They would also be aware of the development of the Anglo-Australian telescope ability. This function has now disappeared into the broader Department of Employment, Education and Training.

The Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) stays with the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones), but primarily it is now within the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce. It is my view that it will not be long before a senior representative from that Department is on the CSIRO board. That raises a very interesting point because there is quite a strong debate going on in the science community at present about what is happening to science and what is happening with regard to basic research and applied research. One move by the Government, which has some support within industry but is being viewed with some concern in the academic community, involves relating all science activity to what the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business described as a slot machine process-one puts a dollar in, pulls a lever and wants to see an automatic result. That approach, of course, has dangers.
An article which I was browsing through this evening contains an interesting quote from Professor David Penington, who is now the Vice-Chancellor of the University of Melbourne. He says this:
Sudden, radical change could damage Australia's scientific and research base in a manner from which it might take many years to recover.

I think we ought to take cognisance of those who are active in the science area, take heed of that warning and not go too far. There needs to be a balance-and I have said that in this place before-between the requirements of basic science and the requirements of applied science. We need to recognise that science is extremely important in providing us with some of the ways out of our current economic difficulties. It does not matter where we sit in this House, all of us recognise that we have major challenges to face with regard to our economy. There is a need to refocus, certainly on developing our added value industries in the manufacturing area, as we have never done before.

At the same time, we need to recognise that bodies such as the CSIRO have had a vital role to play in the past. Certainly in the rural area, the National Farmers Federation has had a lot to say about the reordering of priorities in the CSIRO. All I ask is that there be a recognition by the Government of the importance of science. The people who were in the former Department of Science need to be congratulated for the focus that they brought to science in this country. I refer in particular to the immediate past Secretary, Dr Greg Tegart. He and his officers, under the guidance of the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business-and we give him some credit because he focused attention on science in this nation-should be congratulated for the work that they have done. Let us hope that that good work is not lost to this nation. Science is extremely important. It involves thinking today about the ways that we will deal with problems tomorrow. It would be a very sad day if the Government concentrated only on today's issues and forgot about tomorrow's. Science is one of those areas that we need to be looking at far more closely.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 18 September 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What emergency financial assistance is available to assist persons or families in the ACT in unusual or crisis situations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Punch The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2)-People in crisis or unusual situations needing emergency financial assistance usually approach either the Welfare Services Branch of my Department, or one of the major non-government agencies such as the Salvation Army, St Vincent de Paul, or the Smith Family.
Welfare Services Branch provides emergency financial assistance to-
People who have no cash to provide essential services or goods to ensure the well being of themselves or their dependants
if they have no access to other sources of assistance;
or where their situation is threatened by deferral of expenses or when time payments of accounts cannot be negotiated
in all cases the Director of Welfare or her delegates have the discretion to approve assistance to applicants
assistance might include cash for food, shelter, electricity or travel.
Funding for this service comes from a government appropriation.

The St Vincent de Paul Society provides emergency financial assistance to individuals or families in need. They can also provide assistance in kind, such as food parcels or vouchers. The Society receives funding from the ACT Community Development Fund for these purposes.

The Salvation Army also provides emergency financial assistance to people presenting as being in need. Cash assistance might be to help with electricity bills, rent or rental bonds, bus travel or clothing. Assistance through vouchers for essential items such as clothing is also available.

The Smith Family mainly assist people needing emergency food relief but can also assist people needing electricity, gas, fares or accommodation assistance. The Smith Family look at people's budgets to assess how much money they have to buy food and therefore how much assistance they will need.
Funding of the Salvation Army and the Smith Family for these services comes from the Community Development Fund and from the Department of Community Services and Health's Emergency Relief Program.

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it the intention of the Government to adopt the IAC recommendation for the removal of the tariff on imported grain harvesting machinery; if so, when will this take effect.
(2) Will the 20% tariff currently imposed on imported potato harvesting machinery be removed; if so, from what date will this be effective.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Grain harvesters have entered Australia duty free since August 1985. This resulted from the Government's decision, announced on 27 November 1985, on the IAC's report covering grain harvesters. Duty free entry was backdated to August 1985 for imported grain harvesters.

(2) The Industries Assistance Commission is currently examining the assistance requirements for a wide range of agricultural machinery. The Commission's final report is scheduled to be submitted to the Government in mid 1988. On receipt of the report decisions will be taken on the long term assistance requirements for products such as potato harvesters.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 23 November 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: Are export inspection services carried out by Government agents or contractors on exported (a) high alloy bar products, including stainless steel flat products, quenched and tempered steel plate, cold rolled steel sheet, welded steel pipe and tubes, (b) ships or boats, (c) certain advanced machine tools, including robots, lasers and gas operated machinery which are eligible for payments under the Metal Working Machines and Robots Assistance Scheme and (d) motor vehicles and components; if so, for each product, what is the (i) expense in dollar terms incurred by (A) exporters and (B) the Commonwealth, (ii) total cost of export inspection services and (iii) average percentage cost of export inspection borne by exporters and the Commonwealth.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: I am advised that no Government agency within my portfolio conducts, or contracts out of conduct of, export inspection services on the goods referred to by the honourable member.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Wage Fixing Guidelines: Comparable Worth Concept

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 9 December 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: Is the endorsement given to the concept of comparable worth by the Commonwealth Sex Discrimination Commissioner in the 1985-86 annual report of the Human Rights Commission, consistent with Government policy on wage setting; if so, (a) what studies and research work were undertaken by the Government into the concept prior to a decision being taken on its support and (b) were any cost evaluations undertaken to assess the impact on the economy and the capacity of employers to pay.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Commonwealth Government supported the full application of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission's 1972 equal pay decision and the procedures for implementation as set out therein. It did not support any new procedures or concepts relating to the implementation of equal pay which would have the effect of going beyond the scope of the 1972 decision. The Commonwealth Government submitted to the Commission that ``comparable worth'' as it applied overseas was not relevant to Australian wage fixation and that the term should be approached in a manner consistent with Australian wage fixation principles and practice regarding equal pay.

(a) The former Department of Employment and Industrial Relations carried out research into the implementation of equal pay both in Australia and overseas, including the development of the concept of comparable worth in a range of countries.

(b) The Commonwealth Government submitted that any claims for the implementation of the 1972 equal pay decision should be capable of being processed as anomalies. Such instances would consequently be rare and isolated and the overall labour impact of claims would accordingly be expected to be small.
